(CNN) -- It always made me laugh to hear stories about the insanity that would go on between Robin Williams and Gilbert Gottfried during the making of the movie "Aladdin." The truth was Robin and I didn't bump into each other once during the making of that film. I recorded the Parrot role, and he recorded the Genie separately. So when I saw the film for the first time at the premiere, I was able to laugh along with the rest of the audience at Robin's performance. I had never heard it before.

Welcome to iTOi PRODUCER. This is the SCRIPT area where you write or import your TEXT to read during your video. You can tap the IMPORT icon below to copy text from your clipboard into the script. 
 
Tap the PHOTOS icon found in the center below to preview your SCRIPT and add a photo. 
 
Tap the + icon to add a PHOTO that will display during your recording.  Drag the handles on the photo to control where the photo will appear and disappear. 
 
Tap the GEAR icon at the bottom right to adjust the SPEED and SIZE of the text that will scroll when you record your video. 
 
Now tap the RECORD icon on the right below to get ready to record. You can add a light FILTER, switch between the FRONT and BACK camera, then tap the RED record button to start recording. You will see a 3-second countdown clock before recording actually begins. The app automatically stops your recording when the SCRIPT finished scrolling. 
 
When the recording finishes, you can PLAY the video back, DELETE the video or SAVE it. If you create a FREE  iTOi ACCOUNT, you can save the video in the cloud and then share a LINK to the video or post the video to Twitter and Facebook. 
 
Tap the LIBRARY icon in the lower left of the screen to return home and make another iTOi video.

Hi, my name is Chris Test! I live in Colorado, which is a wonderful place to be a skier. I live about one and a half hours from the mountains, and can be at the ski hill by opening time on any given day in the winter thanks to my new Subaru! In general, I try to get out skiing at least once a month in the winter, if not more.

The World Cup was recently held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. It was really great to see Americans get excited for the World Cup in pubs around the country. This is an app test for usertesting.com.  I have been instructed to create a short presentation using iTOi about my favorite sport.  I have chosen weightlifting.

The sport of weightlifting includes 2 events.  The snatch and the clean and jerk.  Both movements are a determination of how much weight the competitor can get from the ground to over his head.

These events have been used since the early Olympics to determine an athletes overall strength.

Baseball is a great American sport. The basic premise is that two teams compete against each other to score runs. To score a run, one team has one player go up to bat. This player takes a stick made of wood or aluminum and holds it at the ready to hit a small ball that one player pitches to them from the center of the playing field. The batter is allowed three tries to hit the ball before they are "out". Each team is allowed three outs per inning. Another way a player can get "out" is if they run to a base but the teammate manning that base from the other team catches the baseball before the player from the opposing team gets to the base. There are three bases and once a player runs around all three and returns to home plate where they originally started, they score a run. There is much more to the game and rules but this a basic crash course of the game.

Hi.  My name is David.  My favorite sport is baseball.  I started following baseball when it was nine or ten years old.  

My favorite teams are the Marlins and the Rays.   I have never lived in Florida, but I used to go there in the summer every year, so I became a Marlins fan.  

My favorite players are Giancarlo Stanton and David Price.  I used to play baseball a lot with my friends, and I still go to games several times a year with my friends and family.

Gymnastics is a complex competition involving the performance of exercises requiring physical strength, flexibility, power, agility, coordination, grace, balance and control. Internationally, all of the competitive gymnastic events are governed by the Fédération Internationale de Gymnastique (FIG). Each country has its own national governing body (BIW) affiliated to FIG. Competitive artistic gymnastics is the best known of the gymnastic events. It typically involves the women's events of uneven bars, balance beam, floor exercise, and vault. Men's events are floor exercise, pommel horse, still rings, vault, parallel bars, and the high bar. Gymnastics evolved from exercises used by the ancient Greeks that included skills for mounting and dismounting a horse, and from circus performance skills.

What's wrong with death, sir?

What are we so mortally afraid of?

Why can't we treat death with a certain amount of humanity and dignity and decency... and, God forbid, maybe even humor?

Death is not the enemy, gentlemen.

If we're gonna fight a disease, let's fight one of the most terrible diseases of all-- indifference.

Now, I've sat in your schools and heard people lecture on transference...and professional distance.

Transference is inevitable, sir.
Every human being has an impact on another.
Why don't we want that in a patient/doctor relationship?

That's why I've listened to your teachings, and I believe they'r wrong.
A doctor's mission should be not just to prevent death...
but also to improve the quality of life. 

That's why you treat a disease, you win, you lose.   You treat a person, I guarantee you, you win, no matter what the outcome.

(CNN) -- Carolina Panthers defensive end Greg Hardy, who was convicted of domestic violence this summer, did not play Sunday in his team's win over the Detroit Lions.
The news comes amid increased focus on the National Football League and the way it handles players accused of domestic violence.
Until the team's surprising announcement just before game time, Hardy was set to play Sunday. Ray Rice, recently released by the Baltimore Ravens, and Minnesota Vikings star Adrian Peterson won't play either.
Peterson was placed on the inactive list late last week after he was indicted by a grand jury in Texas on a child abuse charge. He tweeted a photo on Sunday of a highlighted religious devotion that cautions people against passing judgment.

AKRON, Ohio -- Laura Zborowski is being called a hero after she sacrificed her life to save a student. The 51-year-old school bus driver was working on an evacuation drill with students outside the Middlebury Academy at the time of the accident.

Police say Zborowski pushed a 10-year-old girl out of the way to safety when a bus started rolling backwards. Moments later, she was struck and later died at the hospital.

Long-time neighbor, Steven Mikel, says he's not surprised by her heroism. "Your character comes through when the chips are down. You react," Mikel told WKYC. "You don't think I want to be around for my son."

Deanna Morrow, a long-time friend and neighbor, says Zborowski leaves behind a 12-year-old son, Tyrese. Morrow said she had raised her son mostly as a single mother and had moved up to Ohio from Texas.

"Really he didn't have a lot of family," Morrow said of the son. "It was just him and his mom for a long time, and then his dad finally came back in the picture. I'm hoping his dad's there for him now."

Morrow used to babysit Tyrese and reports her children grew up with him. Morrow said both son and mother are good people.

Egg-Drop Challenge
Purpose:  
Assigned to design and build a simulated model scale drop delivery system that would protect the cargo (a raw egg) from the distance of Centennial’s rotunda.
Equipment:  
My Egg-Drop contraption is made of Straws, paper towel roll, rubber bands, tape, and plastic grocery bags
Procedure:
1. Widen the paper towel roll
2. Reroll the paper towels
3. Put the straws around the roll.
4. Rubber band the straws to the roll
• I weighed and measured my device.
• I dropped my device from 5.3m in the air and my device landed on the bendy straw legs then fell on to its side. My egg survived.
• We were judged on the dimensions, amount of supplies used, creativity, and the condition of the egg after being dropped from 5.3m in the air.
5.  We were suppose to have a minimum of five supplies
6.  The data was calculated
 
Conclusion:
• My device worked because, I used straws to absorb some of the force of the drop. I also had grocery bags in the paper towel roll to prevent the egg from dropping out the bottom or in case the device flipped on its top.
• I also intentionally placed stronger straws on the outside of the paper towel roll above the bendy straws, to absorb the force in case it fell over on its side.
• I had to split the paper towel roll to make it bigger, and more paper towels could have been added to guarantee that the device would work.
• For a higher height, I would use longer bendy straws and more of them around the outside of the paper towel roll.

A Little Video About ME!

This video is a Grade Level Language Arts assignment TEKS, 1st 6 weeks, 2014-15 School Year

My name is Mrs. Raymond, and I am a grade level teacher in the Dallas area.

My family consists of seven people, my husband, Tim and I, my sons, Christian and Nick, my daughter, Allie, and my husband’s sons, Atticus and Finbar.  We also have a Chihuahua named Bella and a fish.  My husband and I like to go antiquing, walking and garden together.

My favorite things to collect are antiques.  I find it interesting to collect tools, furniture, and pottery from a time gone by.  I find the craftsmanship elegant.

One of my favorite hobbies is gardening.  It is interesting to take a blank piece of grass and plant many different colors and textures that draw different birds and flying insects.

My favorite place that I have visited is New York City.  As a photography enthusiast there are so many grand places and things to photograph.  Above is the nigh-time view of the city from the top of the Empire State Building.

My favorite book is The Best of Me from Nicholas Sparks.  I have enjoyed several of his books.  Several of his books have become movies that I have enjoyed as well, and this movie is due to release in October.  It will be interesting to see if it will be as good as the book.

My favorite subject in school was always and still is anything computer related.  It amazes me the potential of education through technology.

My best friend is my husband, Tim. He warms my heart, makes me laugh, causes me to roll my eyes, brings out the best in me, shakes his head at the silliest of me, and accepts the worst of me and I of him.

That is a little story about me…

The Story of Snow White and the Seven Dwarves

Grimm's Fairy Tale version - translated by Margaret Hunt - language modernized a bit by Leanne Guenther


Once upon a time, long, long ago a king and queen ruled over a distant land.  The queen was kind and lovely and all the people of the realm adored her.  The only sadness in the queen's life was that she wished for a child but did not have one. 

One winter day, the queen was doing needle work while gazing out her ebony window at the new fallen snow.  A bird flew by the window startling the queen and she pricked her finger.  A single drop of blood fell on the snow outside her window.  As she looked at the blood on the snow she said to herself, "Oh, how I wish that I had a daughter that had skin as white as snow, lips as red as blood, and hair as black as ebony."  

Soon after that, the kind queen got her wish when she gave birth to a baby girl who had skin white as snow, lips red as blood, and hair black as ebony.  They named the baby princess Snow White, but sadly, the queen died after giving birth to Snow White.

Soon after, the king married a new woman who was beautiful, but as well proud and cruel.  She had studied dark magic and owned a magic mirror, of which she would daily ask, 

Mirror, mirror on the wall, who's the fairest of them all?

Each time this question was asked, the mirror would give the same answer, "Thou, O Queen, art the fairest of all."  This pleased the queen greatly as she knew that her magical mirror could speak nothing but the truth.

One morning when the queen asked, "Mirror, mirror on the wall, who's the fairest of them all?" she was shocked when it answered:

You, my queen, are fair; it is true.
But Snow White is even fairer than you.
The Queen flew into a jealous rage and ordered her huntsman to take Snow White into the woods to be killed.  She demanded that the huntsman return with Snow White's heart as proof. 

The poor huntsman took Snow White into the forest, but found himself unable to kill the girl.  Instead, he let her go, and brought the queen the heart of a wild boar.

Snow White was now all alone in the great forest, and she did not know what to do.  The trees seemed to whisper to each other, scaring Snow White who began to run.  She ran over sharp stones and through thorns.  She ran as far as her feet could carry her, and just as evening was about to fall she saw a little house and went inside in order to rest.

Inside the house everything was small but tidy.  There was a little table with a tidy, white tablecloth and seven little plates.  Against the wall there were seven little beds, all in a row and covered with quilts.

Because she was so hungry Snow White ate a few vegetables and a little bread from each little plate and from each cup she drank a bit of milk. Afterward, because she was so tired, she lay down on one of the little beds and fell fast asleep.

After dark, the owners of the house returned home.  They were the seven dwarves who mined for gold in the mountains.  As soon as they arrived home, they saw that someone had been there -- for not everything was in the same order as they had left it.

The first one said, "Who has been sitting in my chair?"

The second one, "Who has been eating from my plate?"

The third one, "Who has been eating my bread?"

The fourth one, "Who has been eating my vegetables?"

The fifth one, "Who has been eating with my fork?"

The sixth one, "Who has been drinking from my cup?"

La Cigale et la Fourmi

La Cigale, ayant chanté
Tout l'été,
Se trouva fort dépourvue
Quand la bise fut venue :
Pas un seul petit morceau
Elle alla crier famine
Chez la Fourmi sa voisine,
La priant de lui prêter
Quelque grain pour subsister
Jusqu'à la saison nouvelle.
"Je vous paierai, lui dit-elle,
Avant l'Oût, foi d'animal,
Intérêt et principal. "
La Fourmi n'est pas prêteuse :
C'est là son moindre défaut.
Que faisiez-vous au temps chaud ?
Dit-elle à cette emprunteuse.
- Nuit et jour à tout venant
Je chantais, ne vous déplaise.
- Vous chantiez ? j'en suis fort aise.
Eh bien! dansez maintenant.

Elevator pitch: Noticias Mi CiudadMi nombre es Christy Quesada, comunicadora y máster en gestión de sistemas de saludl... Lo que voy a contarles no es una historia convencional, se trata de Mi Ciudad, Tu Ciudad, Nuestra Ciudad.Yo desperté de un mundo de esos olvidados, opacados por la rutina... Salí de un cuento para pasarme a otro... a un mundo que cobrara vida... Y así conocí Noticias Mi Ciudad... (puede enseñar el libro o el ppt).Hoy usted también puede cambiarse de cuento después de escuchar lo que relatan los antiguos escritos... La Organización Mundial de la Salud dice que los problemas mentales, incluyendo el estrés, representan el 12% del total de la carga global de las enfermedades.Lo que pasa es que esas viejas historias tapan muchos detalles. Aproximadamente 350 millones de personas en nuestro mundo están experimentando depresión, estrés o ansiedad. Y si hablamos de nuestra ciudad, Costa Rica, se han encontrado 31.000 incapacidades, con inversiones cerca de 6.373 millones de colones para comprar fármacos, sedantes o antidepresivos.NOVEDAD DEL SERVICIOPor eso, quisimos convertirnos en STORYTELLERS reales porque estudios demuestran que leer fantasía al menos seis minutos diarios puede reducir el estrés en un 68%. Creamos Noticias Mi Ciudad, emprendimiento que ofrece contenido real convertido en fantasía para mantener al público informado sin estrés y así promover salud mental, empatía y relaciones sociales. Es la combinación de salud mental y fantasía que lo hace novedoso.COMPETENCIA TÉCNICANoticias Mi Ciudad opera como persona física. Christy es la creadora y trabaja con freelancers a nivel latinoamericano. Entre ellos se encuentran: animadores, dibujantes, diseñadores, comunicadores... Sus trabajos han sido pagados por patrocinadores. También se han involucrado inversionistas, donantes y medios de comunicación nacionales e internacionales.(esto solo lo dice si al final el jurado le pregunta: Workana en Argentina, Escáner Cultural en Chile, Librerías Lehmann, Periódico La República, IQ Radio, Museo de los Niños, Bioland, Coca Cola, Sisso Taste of Jerusalem, Ark Mission, Cr Hoy, entre otros).POTENCIAL DE CRECIMIENTONoticias Mi Ciudad tiene un potencial de crecimiento tomando en cuenta un mercado de edades entre los 18 y 40 años. Sabemos que hay una gran demanda para nuestros productos, si se considera el tamaño del problema de la salud mental.¿Qué hemos logrado hasta el momento?Noticias Mi Ciudad se divide en dos etapas:La primera etapa se cumplió en un 100% gracias a patrocinadores. Contiene las siguientes estrategias:Creación de página web con presencia en redes sociales. Ha habido y hay una inversión de tiempo. Se mantiene actualizada.Producción del libro: se contrató a una profesional colombiana para la diagramación y dibujo del mismo.Realización del concurso latinoamericano de literatura fantástica.Organización del mini-festival "Un lugar de Empatía y Fantasía", con su respectivo material publicitario.Creación del personaje Retsé, una producción semanal de historias cortas, donde los textos combinan realidad y fantasía.La segunda etapa contiene las siguientes estrategias:El modelo de negocio está basado en una oferta de servicios en consultoría. Esta oferta continuará, pero vamos a levantar un equipo estable para continuar con la producción. Se iniciaría con dos ilustradores, dos escritores, un programador, un fotógrafo.Se rentabilizaría con la venta de servicios (como se viene haciendo) y con los ingresos publicitarios. La idea es ofrecer el contenido gratuito y que sea pagado por publicidad.¿Cómo lo haríamos?Mediante un noticiero que tendría varias secciones, con temáticas que fueron elegidas por el mismo target mediante un sondeo que se realizó. Se ofrecerían noticias con fantasía.Organización de eventos (dos por año).Editorial que difundiría y vendería obras de autores del Siglo XXI con calidad e innovación.Aplicación interactiva.EL IMPACTO SOCIAL¿Cuál ha sido nuestro impacto social? Noticias Mi Ciudad produjo su propio libro, donde inversionistas apoyaron la impresión de 1000 copias. El libro estuvo en la Feria Internacional del Libro en el stand de Librería Lehmann y ahora se vende en las siete tiendas de esta librería. De hecho hay gente que ya lo está pidiendo en inglés y hebreo.Obtuvimos un premio como emprendimiento en el Congreso Nacional de Innovación en la categoría de Industria Creativa y Cultural.Con nuestro primer mini-festival: “Un Lugar de Fantasía y Empatía” el 27 de septiembre, contamos con una asistencia aproximada de 200 personas, patrocinado por diversas empresas y respaldado por medios de comunicación.La página de Facebook cuenta con aproximadamente 3000 seguidores sin inversión en publicidad, y aún sin poder contabilizar, existen testimonios de personas que se han acercado y están siendo impactadas por Noticias Mi Ciudad.Todo esto es solo una muestra de cómo estamos dando una respuesta a tres problemas principales de la sociedad: estrés, depresión y ansiedad.Con Noticias Mi Ciudad queremos que el viaje se convierta en un storyteller de la VIDA para promover VIDA como un proyecto deVIDA.

Welcome to part two of this Introduction to Sustainable Funding course. This section looks in more detail at where your money comes from, giving you some context about the wider funding environment for the voluntary sector.

All income sources are not created equal. Each type of income has characteristics that make them more appropriate to some organisations, and less so to others.
 
If we take contracts - there are many factors which can affect whether an organisation is able to bid. For example their size, they may not have enough staff with time to put a bid together. Or their track record, many social enterprises I have worked with have found that they were precluded from bidding for contracts because they hadn’t been delivering services for long enough.
 
Many contracts need an organisation to have significant financial resources already, as payment won’t be given until the project is complete. This has meant that commissioners tend to favour larger organisations or those who can form collaborations.
 
Many forms of gift fundraising need an organisation to have a strong relationship with their community or a popular ‘brand’ and strong marketing skills.
 
These different characteristics mean that whilst looking at trends can be useful, you need to be aware of hidden variation.
 
We’re now going to look at some of the main characteristics and trends of each different type of income
 
Gifts are great as they normally give you unrestricted income however they can be unpredictable. You can’t always plan on someone making a large donation or leaving you a bequest. There are lots of different types of donor and ways to give but it takes time build up a strong donor base.
 
Let’s now look at trends in giving, and what you need to think about if you want to increase your income in this area.
 
Firstly we are a nation of givers both in time and money. 65% per cent of adults donated to charitable causes in 2014. Levels of giving by individuals have remained more or less stable over the past 4 years.
 
People are most likely to give to causes that support medical research or children & young people. Other popular causes are overseas aid and hospitals. Health and cultural organisations also provide a strong pull. Donors give to causes that are close to their hearts  and causes that they believe it.

Buying charity merchandise is the most popular method of giving with 50% saying they give to charities this way but this was closely followed by cash with 49% of all donors who gave gave in cash. Women are most likely to give money.
 
Legacies and bequests are an important source of income but still only 7 per cent of people in Australia leave a charitable gift in their will. So this is an untapped market as many people are not aware of the option to leave a gift when they write their will. Don’t be afraid to ask, especially from donors that you know well. As a guide the size of the bequest market in the UK is £2 billion a year or $3.5 billion which is greater than the entire fundraising efforts of Australia combined.
 
If you want to increase gifts you will need to think about donor motivation and why someone would want to give to your cause. This can help you to start thinking about how you could attract that type of donor.
 
It is advisable to offer your donors as many different methods to give as possible however the trends show us that different donor groups can favour different methods of giving. For example online donations are increasing and are favoured by both those aged 25 to 44 and the over 60’s. New research from shows us that there is a real increase in online giving and more is given online than face to face.

Now let’s look at Grants.

A grant is often restricted income which means that the funder has put conditions on what the money is spent on. There is normally a formal (and competitive) application process and the funder has outcomes of their own that they want to be met. Funders will require you to submit monitoring information, to show how you’ve spent the grant. Unspent funds may have to be returned to funder but this is often negotiable. You will normally have a grant agreement, terms and conditions or even a contract
 
We think grants are really important for the voluntary sector, and there are still plenty of grant programmes out there. There’s no doubt, though, that there is increased competition for funds. So let’s look at the other trends
 
Public sector grants still count for a huge proportion of the voluntary sector’s income, though it is likely that government spending cuts will continue into 2016. Many local authorities have scaled back or cut their grant programmes completely.
 
Trusts and Foundations have also reported an increase in the number of ineligible applications and this says two things 1. many organisations are desperate for resources and 2. the scatter gun approach to grant funding doesn’t work as ineligible applications will go straight in the bin.                       

Smaller trusts tend to ‘go with who they know’ – so go back to your funders and make a new proposal to them.
 
Funders are increasingly looking for grant holders to demonstrate the social impact of their work. When done badly, this can increase the monitoring burden on voluntary organisations; however, being able to show your impact is key to attracting new funders and supporters.

There has also been an increase in more engaged grant making. Where grants are offered along with a package of support, think funders like the Impetus Trust.

Now let’s look at Contracts
 
With contracts there is always a restriction on how money is spent. There is usually a formal (and often competitive) application or tender process. Profit can be built in to your bid or tender but you need to consider the legal and financial risks if outcomes or outputs are not delivered. GST applies in many cases, depending on the type of services.
 
The proportion of voluntary sector income from statutory contracts has more than doubled in last 10 years (but with huge variations across the sector). This is in part due to government channelling more funding through a procurement model than a grant model, but also because the sector is gaining experience in winning and delivering contracts.
 
The ‘Opening up public services’ and payment by results agendas are likely to affect organisations involved in delivering contracts in the future

 Payment by Results is the practice of paying providers for delivering services after agreed results have been achieved.

It intends to reward performance, or outcomes, instead of activity, or outputs. It staggers spending and risk between the funder and the provider. If you are not sure what is meant by the terms outcomes and outputs we explain those terms in more depth in part three.
 
So there is a positive motive, but the current reality is that there is a lack of efficiency and transparency, and Payment By Results can be very difficult for organisations that don’t have the resources to deliver before payment.

Finally, we need to think about Consortia and sub-contracting.

Bigger contracts and demand for partnership working increase the need to work together. Consortia and sub-contracting can provide great opportunities to pool skills and resources, but can also be complex and costly to set up, and you need to be careful about allocation of risk.

 So lastly, Trading.
 
Trading provides unrestricted income. It involves a customer transaction, and customers may not be the same people as your beneficiaries.

Something else to note is that you may need to change your legal structure to allow your organisation to trade. Remember that income above certain amount is taxable.

So what are the trends in trading to watch for?
 
We’ve seen a recent growth in ethical consumerism, as well as a growth in finance providers specialising in supporting social enterprise.

 The term ‘Social enterprise’ is increasingly recognised by Government as an important activity in delivering public services.
 
There’s also more public awareness of trading for social benefits, with initiatives like Jamie Oliver’s Fifteen restaurant appearing on mainstream television.

In additional to these four types of income, we’re seeing an increased interest in social investment models, where private finance is used to fund a social and financial return.
 
You may have heard of the ‘Social Impact Bond’, where central government or a social business uses investment from private investors to fund voluntary sector organisations to deliver social outcomes. For example the first UK scheme, launched in 2010 was based on prisoner re-offending rates.
 
If the outcomes are met, government pays back the investors with interest. It is a way of raising capital when it’s needed, and is a form of payment by results. At the moment there are only a few trials with large organisations. However, there are lots of other forms of social investment, such as small loans to help you bridge a funding gap, or overdrafts to help cash flow when you have a large one-off payment to make.
 
So, where do you fit?

Look at the income spectrum exercise from the first part of this training. Bearing in mind the general picture across the sector, how do you feel about the long-term stability of your income? Do you think you have a strong enough mix of income? Or are you reliant on one type?

We have an exercise for you to download below, that will help you assess where your organisation’s income sits at the moment, and where your risks lie.
 
In the final video of this course, we’ll be explaining some key terms and concepts for sustainable funding and exploring how you can assess your organisation’s financial sustainability.
 

Thank you.

Welcome to part three of the Introduction to Sustainable Funding course. This section looks in more detail at how you can improve your organisation’s overall financial health. In particular we’ll be looking at the six areas of sustainability, the sun tool which helps you map how you’re doing across them. We’ll also cover some key terminology and concepts that are crucial for you to understand and use, thinking about your assets and then looking at how you can pull this together into a useful planning process. Finally we’ll suggest some next steps.

 
For this part of the course, you will need the ‘Sustainable Sun Tool’, which you can download below. Pause this if you’d like to print out the download now but don’t worry if you don’t have a printer to hand, I’ll talk you through how to use the tool and you can always print it later.


So, looking at the Sun Tool, the first thing to notice is that income is actually only just one aspect. Our argument is that no organisation can be sustainable unless fundraising and income generation is supported by other areas. So, for instance, if you have trouble with financial management, you may not be able to provide the information needed to support a funding application, or you’ll have trouble managing the financial procedures once you’ve been successful.


To fill out the Sun tool you choose one option from each of the six areas that sounds most like your organisation. You then plot that on the sun – the closer to the middle, the better you’re doing. Then join the dots to make a probably somewhat wonky circle.


Pause this here if you’d like to do this now.


So, how does it look? Is there one area that stands out as needing some urgent work?


You may next want to ask different people within your organisation to complete this tool on their own. Then compare the results. It will be interesting to see where opinions differ and explore why this is. Why don’t you print out a few copies for your next planning day or trustee meeting?

So now we’ll look at some key terms you may come across when looking at income holistically. It is important to understand these, not just because you might hear others using them – particularly funders – but because they contribute to sustainability.

 
The first is Full Cost Recovery.

 
There are lots of different tools available to help you to work out full cost recovery, but the most important thing is to understand what it means and be aware of how it is reflected in your income generating and planning.

 
Full Cost Recovery is a process by which organisations make sure that they are raising the real amount they need to cover the costs of their activities. All too often costs can be ‘hidden’ and therefore not budgeted for and not included in fundraising. For instance, even volunteers are likely to have costs attached to them – they’ll need some sort of management, they might use your building or your stationary and computers. And what would happen if a key volunteer couldn’t help you any more? What would it cost to get this help elsewhere?

 
So, when you’re budgeting, you’ll need to work out how to allocate a proportion of the relevant costs to volunteers and find out their real cost. Then you need to work out how to raise this money. Perhaps you have decided to pay for it from surplus from elsewhere. Or perhaps you can fundraise for them.

Let’s think about some other hidden costs.

A project giving support and advice to young people might have some obvious direct costs – staff time working with the young people, the cost of the venue you’ll be using, maybe paying travel expenses. But there will also be a proportion of lots of other costs – management of the project, of the staff involved and the organisation in general, administrative support, insurance and utility bills. Without deciding how much of these this project is using, you don’t know its full cost. This means that you possibly won’t be raising enough money but also that you might not make the right strategic decisions about which projects are the best use of your organisation’s resources. After all, you want to be achieving the most with the resources that you have.

 
You might want to set up a spreadsheet to work this out – so, for instance, you could enter how much time a project spends in the building, and it could apportion building related costs accordingly. You might want to think about how this varies over time. New projects will always take more management time – and probably more admin too, whereas projects that are coming to the end of a grant will require more fundraising, evaluation and possibly reporting.

 
When you add up all the costs your organisation occurs, you should then be able to see which project is using what.

 
The next key terms, Outputs, Outcomes and Impact, you’ve probably heard of, but it’s amazing how many people don’t really understand what they mean, or don’t remember to make them clear. I’ve marked applications from organisation of different sizes and experience, and the mistake is all too common.
 

Outputs are the things you actually do. So you might deliver a training course, or talk to 20 people, or produce an art work. Outputs are usually tangible and can easily be evidenced. These are the easy things to record.


Outcomes are trickier. They are the things that happened as a result of your outputs. So, you talked to 20 people and as a result, they understood how they could recycle more. How do you demonstrate that they understood? You produce and art work that communicates to visitors to your local shopping centre some of the emotions felt by teenagers. 


So what? That’s your impact – your outputs result in outcomes that lead to a change, an impact – the difference you’ve made to people’s lives or the wider world. Sometimes funding applications only ask for outcomes – they almost always mean impact too. And you should be able to provide some evidence – even if it is ‘soft’ evidence of a case study or a quote. If four of the people on your training course went on to use their new skills to get jobs (the outcome) then so what? Well for one participant, this had the impact that he was able to move to a secure home with his family and his son, Jonny, has been able to settle in at school.

 
It can help to get someone else to check that you are really demonstrating your impact, not just stating your outputs or outcomes. And you should be able to communicate it to anyone, via any media.

To help you to check whether you’re clear on the differences between Outputs, Outcomes and Impact, I’ve written a mini-quiz you can download below.

 
So, moving on, another key piece of terminology is Asset. Assets are, in this case, economic resources. They are things that could be converted into a financial value. Often, organisations have assets that are ‘hidden’. For instance, you may have a building that you are not realising the full value of (how about renting out some space, or even installing solar panels).
 

It could be that your staff or volunteers are hidden assets – could their skills be used to generate income? Or maybe some of your activities could have a double life, producing spin-off publications or training courses?
 

This diagram helps you to think about where your resources lie.

 
This is taken from an excellent report by Caroline Beaumont developed through the Clore Social Leadership programme.

 
If you think back to part one when we thought about income streams, we were talking about how different types of income fit with your organisation. This helps you to look at your organisation in more detail. Think about getting the right income - what you actually need funding for, and what you already have, or could access in kind.

 
Going back to the three Ss – understanding what is suitable is about understanding what you actually need money for, and what you don’t.
 

It’s also about understanding how changing the way you generate income might fit with the culture of your organisation. What steps do you need to take to make it work, to ensure your staff and volunteers are happy with a new approach. If you want to take this exercise a step further, you can download it below.

 
Finally, don’t forget to build in proper planning. Sustainable funding isn’t something that is a discrete activity you can do on your own, or as a one-off. You need to evaluate your mission, build a suitable strategy, craft an achievable plan from that and build in regular reviews. Do you need trigger points for action? (for instance, should certain things have happened by a specific time, or a certain amount of money have been secured?) This planning cycle gives you an example of the types of steps you ought to be taking, but in a way it’s deceptive – you need to be revisiting all the steps regularly.
 

So, this is the end of our Introduction to Sustainable Funding mini-course. What do you need to do now?
 

Decide what your most urgent action needs to be – perhaps the sun tool or the income spectrum could help you.

 
Check the materials you already have – are you communicating your Outputs, Outcomes and Impact clearly? Are you able to justify your costs if asked?

 
Work out any ‘gaps’ in your knowledge, skills or systems that could hold you back.


Make sure you can keep up momentum – it’s very easy to lose sight of your goals when your workload is heavy. Perhaps signing up to our newsletter, booking into a more advanced course or arranging a meeting with relevant people could help.
 

So, in this Introduction to Sustainable Funding course we’ve covered the ‘income spectrum’ – looking beyond raising money from just one source to thinking wider to all potential sources of funding – gifts and donations, grants, contracts, trading and loan finance or social investment. We’ve taken you through some of the features of each of these and the current trends they are experiencing. And then in this section we’ve placed funding in a wider context, showing you a way you can assess how sustainable your organisation is and explaining some key terms you will need to learn.
 

Take a look at the AYMN website for all our sustainable funding tools and resources. Now you’ve completed this introductory course, it might be that you want to take Sustainable Funding further with one of our more advanced. Or, if you think you need more bespoke or in-depth support, then perhaps consultancy would be more suitable. Again, you can find all our resources, including information about AYMN consultancy, on our website. Many of the tools we use in our training courses are free to download too. I hope you’ve found this course helpful. If you take away only two things please remember, 1. Being sustainable is about resource-raising, not fundraising and 2. Sustainable funding can only be successful when integrated and understood by your whole organisation – it is a team activity.

 

Thank you

Welcome to part three of the Introduction to Sustainable Funding course. This section looks in more detail at how you can improve your organisation’s overall financial health. In particular we’ll be looking at the six areas of sustainability, the sun tool which helps you map how you’re doing across them. We’ll also cover some key terminology and concepts that are crucial for you to understand and use, thinking about your assets and then looking at how you can pull this together into a useful planning process. Finally we’ll suggest some next steps.

 

For this part of the course, you will need the ‘Sustainable Sun Tool’, which you can download below. Pause this if you’d like to print out the download now but don’t worry if you don’t have a printer to hand, I’ll talk you through how to use the tool and you can always print it later.

 

So, looking at the Sun Tool, the first thing to notice is that income is actually only just one aspect. Our argument is that no organisation can be sustainable unless fundraising and income generation is supported by other areas. So, for instance, if you have trouble with financial management, you may not be able to provide the information needed to support a funding application, or you’ll have trouble managing the financial procedures once you’ve been successful.

 

To fill out the Sun tool you choose one option from each of the six areas that sounds most like your organisation. You then plot that on the sun – the closer to the middle, the better you’re doing. Then join the dots to make a probably somewhat wonky circle.



Pause this here if you’d like to do this now.



So, how does it look? Is there one area that stands out as needing some urgent work?



You may next want to ask different people within your organisation to complete this tool on their own. Then compare the results. It will be interesting to see where opinions differ and explore why this is. Why don’t you print out a few copies for your next planning day or trustee meeting?

 

So now we’ll look at some key terms you may come across when looking at income holistically. It is important to understand these, not just because you might hear others using them – particularly funders – but because they contribute to sustainability.

 

The first is Full Cost Recovery.

 

There are lots of different tools available to help you to work out full cost recovery, but the most important thing is to understand what it means and be aware of how it is reflected in your income generating and planning.

 

Full Cost Recovery is a process by which organisations make sure that they are raising the real amount they need to cover the costs of their activities. All too often costs can be ‘hidden’ and therefore not budgeted for and not included in fundraising. For instance, even volunteers are likely to have costs attached to them – they’ll need some sort of management, they might use your building or your stationary and computers. And what would happen if a key volunteer couldn’t help you any more? What would it cost to get this help elsewhere?

 

So, when you’re budgeting, you’ll need to work out how to allocate a proportion of the relevant costs to volunteers and find out their real cost. Then you need to work out how to raise this money. Perhaps you have decided to pay for it from surplus from elsewhere. Or perhaps you can fundraise for them.

 

Let’s think about some other hidden costs.

 

A project giving support and advice to young people might have some obvious direct costs – staff time working with the young people, the cost of the venue you’ll be using, maybe paying travel expenses. But there will also be a proportion of lots of other costs – management of the project, of the staff involved and the organisation in general, administrative support, insurance and utility bills. Without deciding how much of these this project is using, you don’t know its full cost. This means that you possibly won’t be raising enough money but also that you might not make the right strategic decisions about which projects are the best use of your organisation’s resources. After all, you want to be achieving the most with the resources that you have.

 

You might want to set up a spreadsheet to work this out – so, for instance, you could enter how much time a project spends in the building, and it could apportion building related costs accordingly. You might want to think about how this varies over time. New projects will always take more management time – and probably more admin too, whereas projects that are coming to the end of a grant will require more fundraising, evaluation and possibly reporting.

 

When you add up all the costs your organisation occurs, you should then be able to see which project is using what

 

The next key terms, Outputs, Outcomes and Impact, you’ve probably heard of, but it’s amazing how many people don’t really understand what they mean, or don’t remember to make them clear. I’ve marked applications from organisation of different sizes and experience, and the mistake is all too common.

 

Outputs are the things you actually do. So you might deliver a training course, or talk to 20 people, or produce an art work. Outputs are usually tangible and can easily be evidenced. These are the easy things to record.

 

Outcomes are trickier. They are the things that happened as a result of your outputs. So, you talked to 20 people and as a result, they understood how they could recycle more. How do you demonstrate that they understood? You produce and art work that communicates to visitors to your local shopping centre some of the emotions felt by teenagers. 

 

So what? That’s your impact – your outputs result in outcomes that lead to a change, an impact – the difference you’ve made to people’s lives or the wider world. Sometimes funding applications only ask for outcomes – they almost always mean impact too. And you should be able to provide some evidence – even if it is ‘soft’ evidence of a case study or a quote. If four of the people on your training course went on to use their new skills to get jobs (the outcome) then so what? Well for one participant, this had the impact that he was able to move to a secure home with his family and his son, Jonny, has been able to settle in at school.

 

It can help to get someone else to check that you are really demonstrating your impact, not just stating your outputs or outcomes. And you should be able to communicate it to anyone, via any media.

To help you to check whether you’re clear on the differences between Outputs, Outcomes and Impact, I’ve written a mini-quiz you can download below.

 

So, moving on, another key piece of terminology is Asset. Assets are, in this case, economic resources. They are things that could be converted into a financial value. Often, organisations have assets that are ‘hidden’. For instance, you may have a building that you are not realising the full value of (how about renting out some space, or even installing solar panels).

 

It could be that your staff or volunteers are hidden assets – could their skills be used to generate income? Or maybe some of your activities could have a double life, producing spin-off publications or training courses?

 

This diagram helps you to think about where your resources lie.

 

This is taken from an excellent report by Caroline Beaumont developed through the Clore Social Leadership programme.

 

If you think back to part one when we thought about income streams, we were talking about how different types of income fit with your organisation. This helps you to look at your organisation in more detail. Think about getting the right income - what you actually need funding for, and what you already have, or could access in kind.

 

Going back to the three Ss – understanding what is suitable is about understanding what you actually need money for, and what you don’t.

 

It’s also about understanding how changing the way you generate income might fit with the culture of your organisation. What steps do you need to take to make it work, to ensure your staff and volunteers are happy with a new approach. If you want to take this exercise a step further, you can download it below.

 

Finally, don’t forget to build in proper planning. Sustainable funding isn’t something that is a discrete activity you can do on your own, or as a one-off. You need to evaluate your mission, build a suitable strategy, craft an achievable plan from that and build in regular reviews. Do you need trigger points for action? (for instance, should certain things have happened by a specific time, or a certain amount of money have been secured?) This planning cycle gives you an example of the types of steps you ought to be taking, but in a way it’s deceptive – you need to be revisiting all the steps regularly.

 

So, this is the end of our Introduction to Sustainable Funding mini-course. What do you need to do now?

 

Decide what your most urgent action needs to be – perhaps the sun tool or the income spectrum could help you.

 

Check the materials you already have – are you communicating your Outputs, Outcomes and Impact clearly? Are you able to justify your costs if asked?

 

Work out any ‘gaps’ in your knowledge, skills or systems that could hold you back.

 

Make sure you can keep up momentum – it’s very easy to lose sight of your goals when your workload is heavy. Perhaps signing up to our newsletter, booking into a more advanced course or arranging a meeting with relevant people could help.

We’ve taken you through some of the features of each of these and the current trends they are experiencing. Hello fellow not-for-profiteers, my name is Bradley Grieve and I’m the CEO of the Australian Youth Mentoring Network and I’m here to welcome you to the first of three instalments of this short course on sustainable funding.

Sustainable funding for many of us is, well, at the same odds of winning the lottery. However, unlike winning the lottery, sustainable funding is a perfectly achievable goal and quite the admirable one too. The reason why sustainable funding seems so distant to many not-for-profits is because of the simple fact that we simply don’t set out with it in mind. We don’t plan for it. We’re too busy focusing on helping others to be bothered to help ourselves. Therefore, and please don’t let the irony be lost on you here, it is the altruistic nature of our sector that is very often hampering our long term objectives of helping others. So this short course is set to help you, and the causes that you set out to address, out of that spiralling hole of unsustainability. So here we go.

This course is conveniently packaged in three parts for easy digestion. In Part one will look at where the money comes from, and as your parents repeatedly told you, it’s not from trees. In Part 2 we will look at the trends of each the income streams, and thirdly we’ll look at the seven habits of highly sustainable programs.

So, let’s not waffle any further, let’s get to it. In this section I’ll do my best to show you the money, but first we need to have a quick chat about the three laws of sustainable funding which are as easy as ABC. In order for funding to be sustainable it must be Appropriate, Balance and Complete.

Appropriateness of funding, relates to the fact that there is no point in having an ample supply of money if it can’t be spent on the projects or the people you’re looking to help. Now, as unbelievable as it may seem, it is true that some rich people are unhappy, and the same applies to projects who accept funding that is inappropriate for them. Often projects accept funding but in order to access it they have to change their vision or mission only to later end up feeling that they have lost their way and compromised their values. So it is important to understand that each organisation is different and needs to find the most appropriate funding for them.

Balanced: This simply means having a wide range of funding sources so your organisation can smooth out the ups and downs

Complete: By having a complete idea of what your real spending is, you can raise enough income to cover your costs.

So, with the basic understanding of the laws of sustainability, we can now turn our attention to where the money comes from. And here, in a break from tradition, there are four streams of income where going to look at, Donations, Grants, Contracts and Trading.

We’ll start with Donations.

Donations are made by individuals typically for charitable purposes or to benefit a cause, or sometimes simply for a tax deduction. And donations take various forms including gifts of cash, services, new or used goods including clothing, toys, food, and vehicles. However, more often than not it is cash that people give, and women give more than men.  Come on guys, lift your game.

Second is Grants. By grants we mean restricted funding to deliver specific work, often received after an application process. Grants are good, but they can be addictive and are increasingly hard to come by.

The next income stream is Contracts. These usually involve payment for provision of products or services according to agreed terms. Contracts are often between not-for-profit organisations and public bodies such as Governments or local councils.

And finally, we have trading, this means selling products or services to customers. Trading can include providing services or advice for a fee, or selling a product like a book. There is no difference here between a for-profit business and a charity. For all the casual customer knows, it’s just another snappy business selling the latest and greatest fandangles.

So, those are the four main income streams and we’ll explore these in more detail in Part 2.

But there are also some other things to consider alongside the income streams.

Whether income is from a donor or a customer can sometimes be a tricky question. It all depends on whether the person who gave the gift is considered to be getting something other warm and fuzzy feelings in exchange for their money. If they are, they are a customer, if not, they are a donor. And this of course can affect tax deductibility for our kindly patrons so you’d better get it right or beware the screaming banshee that is the Tax Man.

For some very lucky organisations there is also stuff called investment income. Investment income includes rent from property, dividends and interest on deposits. For most of us, investment income is as rare as a unicorn with hen’s teeth riding a magic carpet, as it represents such a small share of overall income, but for some organisations it is very important.

Now that we’ve found where money comes from, and that really is the easy bit, what happens next? Well, knowledge is only power if it takes the form of action so we’ll look at the steps you need to take.

Your first priority should be to take a look at your organisation to see where you fit. Ask yourself which of the four streams is your biggest source of income. Then see if you can put a figure on each of the four categories, working out the percentage in each income stream. Finally, work out how many different sources of income are within that income stream, for example you may have 100 individual donors or five different grants coming into your organisation.

You might want to pause the video at this point and work out your biggest source of income, how much of your income is in each stream, and how many contributors you have in each of the four streams.

Once you have answered these questions, you can start to see if your income mix is risky. For example, if all your money is coming from one stream then you may be over-dependent on that type of income. Also, if your income streams are all ending soon this is another risk factor.

So what happens if after the exercise you find that you are extraordinarily focused on a narrow stream of income, what are you supposed to do to go about diversifying your income?

There are different ways that you could diversify. One is to spread out across the income spectrum. By developing new income in different streams you can spread your risk. For example you can diversify away from grant dependence by developing your donor base, bringing in much more gift income. You can get cracking straight away with community fundraising activities and developing relationships with potential donors. Another way that you could diversify your income is by bringing in more from existing income streams. For example, you could use a funding search website to start exploring new grant and contract opportunities for your organisation.

The vital thing to remember about diversifying is that there is no magic formula for your organisation’s income. You could have a mix across all the income streams, or you could specialise in one of the four types of income. The trick here is to not narrow your options, rather just get out there and play the funding field.

But remember that money is just one piece of the puzzle. Other important factors include your organisation’s mission, vision and values, keeping those at the centre of the work you do. Also, you will need to have the right people in place to do your fundraising and income generation. Have you got the right skills already or do you need to invest in training or get in specialist advice?

Finally, measuring and reporting your impact is getting more and more important to show to funders and supporters that you are achieving real change in the world.

So Sustainable Funding is about planning– considering all the different sources of income, plus the context and environment that your work in. Remember the ABCs - and look for income that is Appropriate, Balanced, and Complete.

In this section of the course we have covered the ABCs of the sustainable funding approach and the four main income streams, Donations, Grants, Contracts and Trading.

So that’s your lot of the this section so I hope you’ll join us in the next part of the course where we’ll be exploring the characteristics of different income streams and current trends.

Will your schedule permit a 30minute introductory call next Wednesday?

Looking forward to speaking with you and have a great day.

Hello.

I’m Paul Peck.

I’m going to share with you a few images that help explain my background.

Over the course of my career, I’ve been hired a dozen times.
And I helped 6 of those companies through a merger acquisition process.
Later in my career, I went into consulting, for 8 more firms.

Here is the run-down on my unusually diverse background.  

I went to Texas Tech University.  I joined Texas Instruments a year before I graduated.
In my senior year, I was simultaneously a full time student and a full time employee.  I helped TI launch Calculators, Watches, and the famous Speak and Spell text-to speech processing learning aid.  I graduated on time, and stayed at TI long enough for them to pay for my MBA.

After TI, I moved back to my hometown, Fort Worth, and joined General Dynamics
I ran materials management programs, and worked on the start-up of the F-16 program, as well as special projects for NASA.

I was recruited by ex-TIers to join DanRay, one of the first companies in the Telecom Corridor.
At DanRay, I became Materials Manager and Industrial Engineering Manager - simultaneously.
That company made the very first switching systems for MCI and Sprint, and was later bought by Nortel

After Nortel, I became a business systems consultant for Xerox Computer Services.  I specialized in Sales support and system implementation.
At XCS, we had one of the first cloud-computing ERP systems, and we introduced the world’s first desktop computers that had GUI screens and a mouse.

I was hired by an XCS client to run their operations, and ultimately became the general manager of the business.
I managed that company through an acquisition, the licensing of their technology, and the ultimate sale to Davox Corporation.
After Davox the licensee hired me to run a new business unit where we pioneered automated operator services.

During this time I pursued an old dream - to become an expert in accounting and get a CPA license.  I took the additional courses I needed at UT-Dallas and passed all 5 sections of the 3 day exam on the first try.  Then, I was finally prepared for dealing with all those corporate bean counters who wanted to tell me what the “rules” are.

I was recruited by DSC Communications, helped the company divisionalize, ran one of the 1st divisions, and ultimately became VP of global manufacturing, with over 1,800 people and shipping nearly $2 billion a year, or as I like to say, $1 million an hour.  At DSC I helped us buy and run the TI business unit that invented text-to-speech processing.  ET phoned home, from my point of view.  Later I became DSC’s GM for the Japan business unit, where my development team introduced automated roaming and the worlds first wireless texting system.  DSC was bought by Alcatel, where I remained as their VP of the Asian business unit. for a while.

I left Alcatel to join the start-up Monterey Networks as VP of Manufacturing.  At Monterey, we designed and built the world’s largest optical router, and in less that 16 months, we took Monterey from a $10 million A-Round to a $550 million exit when we were purchased by Cisco Systems.  I stayed with Cisco for another 18 months, vesting bur nor resting - I helped Cisco developing a product launch process for the telecom service provider segment that were just entering.  After Cisco, I joined another stat-up that was ultimately acquired by Cisco, Navini Networks, makers of some of the most advanced wireless systems outside the military.

After Navini, I joined Covaro Networks as VP of Operations.  We developed telecom solutions that extended high-speed Ethernet to the end user.  Covaro was bought by ADVA Optical Networking of Germany, where I became BOTH Global VP of Quality Management AND VP of Strategic Materials Management AND integration executive for the purchase of Movaz Networks - again- simultaneously.  I left ADVA to join a supplier, Menara Networks, as Chief Financial Officer.  I helped the maker of miniaturized long-haul optical devices set up their accounting process, and heir outsourced materials and manufacturing process.

I left Menara to take on a series of lucrative consulting engagements, by specializing in engineering systems, product launch, and business systems.  One of these companies was Global Supply Chain Solutions, where I helped manage through a business restructuring and acquisition.  The new owners asked me to become interim CEO for their 1st 2 years of ownership.

Other companies for which I’ve been a consultant include pioneers in mass storage, digital wallet, industrialized tablets, high-performance computing, long-haul microwave, and LED lighting.  One client was the top recipient from the Texas Emerging Technology Fund, and another was a Shark-Tank investment recipient, by Mark Cuban, no less, on my watch as their contract CFO.

Another client, 70-year-old Weathermatic, asked me to become their first combination COO/CFO.  At Weathermatic, I completed the implementation of their cloud-based ERP system, put in on-line budgeting, on-line purchasing, and on-line expense reimbursement.  We also engaged a new audit firm and new legal counsel, and upgraded those processes as well.  And perhaps best - a 2 day financial close process.

I have extensive international experience, having held executive positions with several multi-national companies, and have had either customers, operations or key suppliers all over the world.  I am quite comfortable with setting up global supply and value-add chains on an international basis.  I’m one of those guys that has had to get extra pages put in his passport before it expires.

So there you have it - I’ve worn just about every kind of hat there is to wear, in all sorts of situations, for all kinds of companies.  And I’m proud to say that I am a survivor of every event where my company was purchased.  That’s not likely unless you know how to make the trains run on time.
As you can imagine, as a result of all this, I have quite a bit of experience in target acquisition, due diligence, and acquisition integration.

I’m very active in the community.  At the local level, I’m vice chair and treasurer of the largest economic development trade organization in Texas. I’m on the Mayor’s task force for International Business, and on the City’s tax increment financing board.  I’m on two boards at the University of Texas at Dallas and frequent guest lecturer.  I’ll do just about anything to advance the cause of investment, economic development and education.

Personally, I have a few hobbies - My wife and I are extreme sightseeing travelers, and I’m a vintage technology collector.  

I have to confess to being a car guy.  One of my favorite pastimes is amateur motorsports, and I am quite the track-school enthusiast.  I’m not that good, but I did manage to win a 1st place trophy from the BMW International Driving School at the Nurburgring in Germany.  

My wife is a realtor-broker, and together, we are not only real estate property owners, but also real estate developers.  We live in a small subdivision we developed, on a street we named.

If you need help in any of the following areas, which comprise just about very area there is in most technology businesses, please let me know.  If I can’t help you, I bet I can help you find someone that can.

Thanks for taking time to hear my story, and to consider how I might be able to help you.

The Story of Snow White and the Seven Dwarves

Grimm's Fairy Tale version - translated by Margaret Hunt - language modernized a bit by Leanne Guenther


Once upon a time, long, long ago a king and queen ruled over a distant land.  The queen was kind and lovely and all the people of the realm adored her.  The only sadness in the queen's life was that she wished for a child but did not have one. 

One winter day, the queen was doing needle work while gazing out her ebony window at the new fallen snow.  A bird flew by the window startling the queen and she pricked her finger.  A single drop of blood fell on the snow outside her window.  As she looked at the blood on the snow she said to herself, "Oh, how I wish that I had a daughter that had skin as white as snow, lips as red as blood, and hair as black as ebony."  

Soon after that, the kind queen got her wish when she gave birth to a baby girl who had skin white as snow, lips red as blood, and hair black as ebony.  They named the baby princess Snow White, but sadly, the queen died after giving birth to Snow White.

Soon after, the king married a new woman who was beautiful, but as well proud and cruel.  She had studied dark magic and owned a magic mirror, of which she would daily ask, 

Mirror, mirror on the wall, who's the fairest of them all?

Each time this question was asked, the mirror would give the same answer, "Thou, O Queen, art the fairest of all."  This pleased the queen greatly as she knew that her magical mirror could speak nothing but the truth.

One morning when the queen asked, "Mirror, mirror on the wall, who's the fairest of them all?" she was shocked when it answered:

You, my queen, are fair; it is true.
But Snow White is even fairer than you.
The Queen flew into a jealous rage and ordered her huntsman to take Snow White into the woods to be killed.  She demanded that the huntsman return with Snow White's heart as proof. 

The poor huntsman took Snow White into the forest, but found himself unable to kill the girl.  Instead, he let her go, and brought the queen the heart of a wild boar.

Snow White was now all alone in the great forest, and she did not know what to do.  The trees seemed to whisper to each other, scaring Snow White who began to run.  She ran over sharp stones and through thorns.  She ran as far as her feet could carry her, and just as evening was about to fall she saw a little house and went inside in order to rest.

Inside the house everything was small but tidy.  There was a little table with a tidy, white tablecloth and seven little plates.  Against the wall there were seven little beds, all in a row and covered with quilts.

Because she was so hungry Snow White ate a few vegetables and a little bread from each little plate and from each cup she drank a bit of milk. Afterward, because she was so tired, she lay down on one of the little beds and fell fast asleep.

After dark, the owners of the house returned home.  They were the seven dwarves who mined for gold in the mountains.  As soon as they arrived home, they saw that someone had been there -- for not everything was in the same order as they had left it.

The first one said, "Who has been sitting in my chair?"

The second one, "Who has been eating from my plate?"

The third one, "Who has been eating my bread?"

The fourth one, "Who has been eating my vegetables?"

The fifth one, "Who has been eating with my fork?"

The sixth one, "Who has been drinking from my cup?"

Wendy, John, and Michael Darling lived in London. One night, Wendy woke to find a strange boy sitting on the floor who was crying.
"My name is Wendy," she said. "Who are you? Why are you crying?
"I'm Peter Pan," the boy replied. "I'm crying because my shadow won't stick to me."
"Don't cry," Wendy said. "We can fix that." And she sewed Peter's shadow to the tips of his shoes. Peter was delighted.
"Fly back to Neverland with me and my fairy, Tinker Bell," Peter begged. "You could be our mother and take care of us."
"Can you teach me to fly?" Wendy asked. Peter nodded.
"Let's wake John and Michael," Wendy said. "You can teach us all to fly and then we will leave for Neverland!”
The children were soon flying around the room. Then—Swoosh! Out the window they all flew.
Wendy, John, and Michael flew behind Peter Pan and Tinker Bell, following the golden arrows that pointed the way to Neverland. Finally, they were flying over the island.
"The lost boys live with me and Tinker Bell. I'm their captain," Peter said. "The Indians live over there, and the mermaids live in the lagoon. And there are pirates too, led by Captain Hook."

Our project today describes a study (Daniels, 2012) that looked at the impact of sexualized images of athletes compared to performance pictures on women’s perceptions of the athlete’s and of themselves. Women looked at different types of pictures (Picture) and then did a writing task. Daniels identified whether certain themes were present or absent in each written piece (Theme_Present). We have already looked at the self-evaluation theme, but Daniels also identified others including: commenting on the athlete’s body/appearance (Athletes_Body), indicating admiration or jealousy for the athlete (Admiration), indicating that the athlete was a role model or motivating (Role_Model), and their own physical activity (Self_ Physical_Activity). Further, I’ll include complimentary access to my new advanced negotiating program, Breakthrough Negotiating II:  Game Changing Strategies.  

Whereas the Breakthrough Negotiating program focuses on skills you can employ to negotiate successfully at the table, Breakthrough Negotiating II focuses on strategies you can employ away from the table to set the table before you sit at the table and win the game before the game even begins.

Registration for this course is also $1,497, but you’ll get it for free if you register now. results.projectTitle: Principal's Message 10-27-14: Going To School Virtually
results.script:
Good day everyone!
 
This week's message is about "going to school – virtually". This message is focused on those of you who are “full time” in our DVIA program. While much of what I will address is applicable to all students, part time as well, the ones I hope hear me today are our full time students and their parents.
 
As I review attendance, participation, and academic achievement data, I am discovering a very real issue that affects our entire school. That issue is: what does "going to school" mean in a virtual setting.
 
One of the major benefits of being a full time DVIA student is the ability to schedule your academic work ‘around’ other activities and events in your life, regardless of what they might be. However, that cannot mean “putting off” today’s work repeatedly. In your LMS there is a progress report. You will notice the pacing or completion of your individual courses. You will see the your progress indicated by bars.
 
If you are near (within a couple of % points), equal to, or are ahead of the pacing, that bar becomes “blue”. This is Great!!!
 
I point these out as a reference for you to consider when you review your status.

If you are “in the blue”, you are on pace and moving ahead according to plan. You have likely developed your academic plan and schedule and are following it appropriately. Great job!
 
If you are “in the red”, you have a need to review your current schedule and the time you commit to your courses.
 
If you were in a ‘brick and mortar’ school, you would be spending approximately 6 hours a day in dedicated academic work. You would also have from 1 to 3 hours of after school/home work to do. This totals about 8 hours a day of commitment to ‘going to school’. While we know that our virtual world is a bit more time efficient, we also know that you must commit an average of 6 hours a day for 5 days a week to remain on the appropriate pace to complete each course. For those taking 6 courses, that would equate to approximately 30 hours of dedicated work on your academics each week!!
 
YOU MUST GO TO SCHOOL….. you must create a schedule of your time for “going to school”. Going to school IS the reason you are enrolled with us. We ARE your school and you ARE our student.
 
Parents, I cannot stress enough the importance of your role is assisting and supporting your child in the development of a routine on a daily basis. The routine may vary from day to day. It may vary the courses on certain days. It may look substantially different from prior weeks due to a change in focus. However, one thing should remain the same: commitment to maintaining consistent progress by ensuring time on task is dedicated.
 
Many of you are finding yourselves behind. The attitude might be that you can always catch up. But you must keep in mind that ‘catching up’ does not mean skipping any required lessons or the assignments. You must “do the work”.
 
“Do the work”….translation: Go to School….
 
While you clearly are not ‘going to a brick and mortar’ school, you MUST “go to school” regularly and consistently to be successful academically. You must establish your routine or you will find yourself being very random with your efforts and your success will be decreasing.
 
Confidence is great when applied with focus. Confidence is a killer when used as a crutch to defend procrastination! Put your confident attitudes of success and good grades in action with a plan – focus – follow up – complete your work!
 
I leave you today by repeating the statement: GO TO SCHOOL….virtually!

Hey everyone! For those of you who may not know me, my name is Tausha Cameron and I am the Administrative Assistant here at Victory! Pastor Dan wanted me to share a little bit about my experience and my mission field it’s kinda unique and it just so happens to be in the pageant industry.
When most people hear the word “pageant” they associate it with facial beauty and lots and lots of make-up, maybe even a girl trying to be something that they’re not. That couldn’t be any further from the truth in the case of scholarship pageantry and the pageants I have taken part in and will continue to be involved in. There are many pageant organizations that hold high moral standards for their contestants and title holders… and when I compete I take those standards to the next level!
My whole life I have strived to not only be seen as a positive role model but act upon that behavior. I believe a true role model lives by example and lives their life how you would want your child to live their life. That is with integrity, modesty, and compassion. Ministry is my passion and Scholarship Pageantry happens to be my hobby. With the opportunities I have been given to represent Wisconsin numerous of times with a variety of organizations I am enabled to combine them both, all while representing Christ.
This past summer I was able to go to Virginia Beach, Virginia to represent Wisconsin at Internationals. There were girls from all over the world! And one of many girls I got to know well and became close with was BreAnna, Miss Washington! To make a long story short we had A LOT in common all accept a relationship with Christ. Still to this day we text and I am able to encourage her and pray with her.
I would have loved to talk to you all about my mission field live but I’m actually in Iowa encouraging my way to be the next Miss Wisconsin for America’s U.S. Miss but at these pageants I am able to pray with the girls I meet that week or weekend I am able to share how God turned my Tests into my Testimony and even stir up great conversation with the judges I meet in the one on one interview process. I have made a number of lifelong friendships with these girls by stepping out in faith and sharing God’s love. I am even able to stay in contact with them through social media and be an encouragement in their lives. 
I want to thank you all for listening to my little snippet of my mission field. And I want to leave you with this… I may wear a crown or a tiara but I serve the the one true king who sits on the ultimate throne and has a reign that never ends now pageantry is my mission field kind a unique kind a different right, I want you to ask yourself… what is your mission field?
