Part 1: Introduction to Sustainable Funding

Hello, I’m Bradley Grieve the CEO of the Australian Youth Mentoring Network or the AYMN.

The AYMN is the national peak body for the youth mentoring sector and exists to strengthen the youth mentoring sector and champion all that it does.

At the beginning of 2013 we started our work on sustainable funding because it was important to look at funding and income holistically rather than focusing on one type of funding.

Following that philosophy, we have developed a range of tools and resources to help organisations be more financially sustainable.

By the end of this course you will understand what sustainable funding is, and how it could work for your organisation. You will have learned about the main sources of income and their characteristics, and you will have improved your knowledge on the trends in the not-for-profit sector economy, and how they affect your organisation. You will also have the skills to implement a more sustainable approach to funding in your work.

The course is in three parts.

In part one, we look at what sustainable funding means and introduce the four main income streams.

In part two, we will look more closely at the different types of income, what they are like to work with and the trends happening right now.

And in part three, we will look at how you can use the sustainable sun tool and the resource raising approach to embed sustainable funding across your organisation’s work.

So what do we mean by sustainable funding? One way to look at it is to use our ‘ABC of sustainable funding.  Sustainable funding is Appropriate, Balanced and Complete.

Appropriate: each organisation is different and needs to find the most appropriate funding for them

Balanced: means having a wide range of funding sources so your organisation can smooth out the ups and downs

Complete: by having a complete idea of what your real spending is you can raise enough income to cover your costs.

By following the ABCs you can work out whether an income stream will be right for you, looking at whether it is Appropriate, Balanced and Complete.

Now we’ll turn to the types of funding and income. We split them up into four main categories shown here on our ‘income spectrum’, Gifts, Grants, Contracts and Trading.

The first is Gifts.

Gifts are made by individuals to further the mission of an organisation. They might include community fundraising, individual giving, philanthropy and some kinds of corporate support. Here the relationship is with a “donor”.

Second is Grants. By grants we mean restricted funding to deliver specific work, often received after an application process. Here there is a relationship with a “funder”.

The next income stream is Contracts. These usually involve payment for provision of products or services according to agreed terms. Contracts are often between voluntary organisations and public bodies such as Governments or local councils. The relationship here is with a “purchaser”.

Finally we have Trading, This means selling products or services to customers, not as part of a long-term structured contract. Trading and enterprise activity can include providing services or advice for a fee, or selling a product like a book. The relationship here is with a “customer”.

Those are the four income streams in the income spectrum, and the vast majority of money in the not-for-profit sector fits into one of these categories. We’ll look at all four in more detail in the second part of this course.

But there are also some other things to consider alongside the income streams.

Whether income is from a donor or a customer can sometimes be a tricky question. Income from sponsorship, membership or fundraising events can be considered gifts, or they can be in the open market. It depends on whether the person or organisation is understood to be getting a product or service in exchange for their money. If they are, they are a customer, if not, they are a donor. And this difference can affect tax deductibility for the giver.

Another thing to consider is Social Investment: Social investment sits outside the income spectrum, and can be used as a financial enabler, allowing your organisation to develop new projects, property, or anything else where finance is required.

Investment income includes rent from property, dividends and interest on deposits. This investment income represents a small share of the voluntary sector’s overall income, but for some organisations it is very important.

Going back to the income spectrum, now we’ve mapped it out, what do you do next?

Well your first priority should be to take a look at your organisation to see where you fit. First of all, ask yourself which of the four streams is your biggest source of income. Then see if you can put a figure on the different categories, working out the percentage in each income stream. Finally, work out how many different sources of income are within that income stream, for example you may have 100 individual donors or five different grants coming into your organisation.

You might want to pause the video at this point and work out your biggest source of income, how much of your income is in each stream, and how many contributors you have in each of the four streams.

Once you have answered these questions, you can start to see if your income mix is risky. For example, if all your money is coming from one stream then you may be over-dependent on that type of income. Also, if your income streams are all ending soon this is another risk factor.

To take an example, I helped a Community Group to review their income from the current financial year. They had received a one-off grant of $25,000 from the government, and an annual grant of $5,000 from the local council (agreed for another three years). They also raised about $2000 from a community event.

This meant that the Group had $32,000 in the grants column of the income spectrum, which was 95 per cent of their income, a very high proportion. Our review also showed that 80 per cent of their income was ending this year and was unlikely to be renewed, so their income was very risky.

They needed to start planning right away to either scale back their expenditure quickly, or diversify and increase their income.

So how would the Group go about diversifying their income?

There are different ways that they could diversify. One is to spread out across the income spectrum. By developing new income in different streams they could spread the risk. For example the community group could diversify away from grant dependence by further developing their donor base, bringing in much more gift income. They could set about straight away with community fundraising activities and developing relationships with potential donors.

Another way that they could diversify their income is by bringing in more from existing income streams. For example, the community group had already secured two grants for their work. They could target other grant-makers to ensure that they weren’t so reliant on the income from the government and the council.  They could use a funding search website like to start exploring new grant and contract opportunities for their organisation.

The vital thing to remember about diversifying is that there is no magic formula for your organisation’s income. You could have a mix across all the income streams, or you could specialise in one of the four types of income. The trick is to not narrow your options.

But remember that money is just one piece of the puzzle. Other important factors include your organisation’s mission, vision and values, keeping those at the centre of the work you do. Also, you will need to have the right people in place to do your fundraising and income generation. Have you got the right skills already or do you need to invest in training or get in specialist advice? Last year we helped a number of organisations, through our training and consultancy, to improve their funding skills and strategies.

Finally, measuring and reporting your impact is getting more and more important to show to funders and supporters that you are achieving real change in the world.

So Sustainable Funding is about planning your income holistically – all the different sources of income, plus the context and environment that is needed to support and enable financial sustainability for your work. Remember the ABCs - and look for income that is Appropriate, Balanced, and Complete.

In this section of the course we have covered the sustainable funding approach and the four main income streams, Gifts, Grants, Contracts and Trading.

In the next part of the course, we’ll be exploring more closely the characteristics of different income streams and current trends, and how sustainable funding works across your whole organisation.


Thank you.

Welcome to part three of the Introduction to Sustainable Funding course. This section looks in more detail at how you can improve your organisation’s overall financial health. In particular we’ll be looking at the six areas of sustainability, the sun tool which helps you map how you’re doing across them. We’ll also cover some key terminology and concepts that are crucial for you to understand and use, thinking about your assets and then looking at how you can pull this together into a useful planning process. Finally we’ll suggest some next steps.

 

For this part of the course, you will need the ‘Sustainable Sun Tool’, which you can download below. Pause this if you’d like to print out the download now but don’t worry if you don’t have a printer to hand, I’ll talk you through how to use the tool and you can always print it later.

 

So, looking at the Sun Tool, the first thing to notice is that income is actually only just one aspect. Our argument is that no organisation can be sustainable unless fundraising and income generation is supported by other areas. So, for instance, if you have trouble with financial management, you may not be able to provide the information needed to support a funding application, or you’ll have trouble managing the financial procedures once you’ve been successful.

 

To fill out the Sun tool you choose one option from each of the six areas that sounds most like your organisation. You then plot that on the sun – the closer to the middle, the better you’re doing. Then join the dots to make a probably somewhat wonky circle.



Pause this here if you’d like to do this now.



So, how does it look? Is there one area that stands out as needing some urgent work?



You may next want to ask different people within your organisation to complete this tool on their own. Then compare the results. It will be interesting to see where opinions differ and explore why this is. Why don’t you print out a few copies for your next planning day or trustee meeting?

 

So now we’ll look at some key terms you may come across when looking at income holistically. It is important to understand these, not just because you might hear others using them – particularly funders – but because they contribute to sustainability.

 

The first is Full Cost Recovery.

 

There are lots of different tools available to help you to work out full cost recovery, but the most important thing is to understand what it means and be aware of how it is reflected in your income generating and planning.

 

Full Cost Recovery is a process by which organisations make sure that they are raising the real amount they need to cover the costs of their activities. All too often costs can be ‘hidden’ and therefore not budgeted for and not included in fundraising. For instance, even volunteers are likely to have costs attached to them – they’ll need some sort of management, they might use your building or your stationary and computers. And what would happen if a key volunteer couldn’t help you any more? What would it cost to get this help elsewhere?

 

So, when you’re budgeting, you’ll need to work out how to allocate a proportion of the relevant costs to volunteers and find out their real cost. Then you need to work out how to raise this money. Perhaps you have decided to pay for it from surplus from elsewhere. Or perhaps you can fundraise for them.

 

Let’s think about some other hidden costs.

 

A project giving support and advice to young people might have some obvious direct costs – staff time working with the young people, the cost of the venue you’ll be using, maybe paying travel expenses. But there will also be a proportion of lots of other costs – management of the project, of the staff involved and the organisation in general, administrative support, insurance and utility bills. Without deciding how much of these this project is using, you don’t know its full cost. This means that you possibly won’t be raising enough money but also that you might not make the right strategic decisions about which projects are the best use of your organisation’s resources. After all, you want to be achieving the most with the resources that you have.

 

You might want to set up a spreadsheet to work this out – so, for instance, you could enter how much time a project spends in the building, and it could apportion building related costs accordingly. You might want to think about how this varies over time. New projects will always take more management time – and probably more admin too, whereas projects that are coming to the end of a grant will require more fundraising, evaluation and possibly reporting.

 

When you add up all the costs your organisation occurs, you should then be able to see which project is using what.

 

We have an example case study from BTCV (the Brisbane Trust for Conservation Volunteers) on our website that describes how they went about setting up a system for Full Cost Recovery. Your system doesn’t have to be flawless – in fact, most are a work in progress, but it does have to give you a good idea of where your resources are being used.

 

The next key terms, Outputs, Outcomes and Impact, you’ve probably heard of, but it’s amazing how many people don’t really understand what they mean, or don’t remember to make them clear. I’ve marked applications from organisation of different sizes and experience, and the mistake is all too common.

 

Outputs are the things you actually do. So you might deliver a training course, or talk to 20 people, or produce an art work. Outputs are usually tangible and can easily be evidenced. These are the easy things to record.

 

Outcomes are trickier. They are the things that happened as a result of your outputs. So, you talked to 20 people and as a result, they understood how they could recycle more. How do you demonstrate that they understood? You produce and art work that communicates to visitors to your local shopping centre some of the emotions felt by teenagers. 

 

So what? That’s your impact – your outputs result in outcomes that lead to a change, an impact – the difference you’ve made to people’s lives or the wider world. Sometimes funding applications only ask for outcomes – they almost always mean impact too. And you should be able to provide some evidence – even if it is ‘soft’ evidence of a case study or a quote. If four of the people on your training course went on to use their new skills to get jobs (the outcome) then so what? Well for one participant, this had the impact that he was able to move to a secure home with his family and his son, Jonny, has been able to settle in at school.

 

It can help to get someone else to check that you are really demonstrating your impact, not just stating your outputs or outcomes. And you should be able to communicate it to anyone, via any media.

To help you to check whether you’re clear on the differences between Outputs, Outcomes and Impact, I’ve written a mini-quiz you can download below.

 

So, moving on, another key piece of terminology is Asset. Assets are, in this case, economic resources. They are things that could be converted into a financial value. Often, organisations have assets that are ‘hidden’. For instance, you may have a building that you are not realising the full value of (how about renting out some space, or even installing solar panels).

 

It could be that your staff or volunteers are hidden assets – could their skills be used to generate income? Or maybe some of your activities could have a double life, producing spin-off publications or training courses?

 

This diagram helps you to think about where your resources lie.

 

This is taken from an excellent report by Caroline Beaumont developed through the Clore Social Leadership programme.

 

If you think back to part one when we thought about income streams, we were talking about how different types of income fit with your organisation. This helps you to look at your organisation in more detail. Think about getting the right income - what you actually need funding for, and what you already have, or could access in kind.

 

Going back to the three Ss – understanding what is suitable is about understanding what you actually need money for, and what you don’t.

 

It’s also about understanding how changing the way you generate income might fit with the culture of your organisation. What steps do you need to take to make it work, to ensure your staff and volunteers are happy with a new approach. If you want to take this exercise a step further, you can download it below.

 

Finally, don’t forget to build in proper planning. Sustainable funding isn’t something that is a discrete activity you can do on your own, or as a one-off. You need to evaluate your mission, build a suitable strategy, craft an achievable plan from that and build in regular reviews. Do you need trigger points for action? (for instance, should certain things have happened by a specific time, or a certain amount of money have been secured?) This planning cycle gives you an example of the types of steps you ought to be taking, but in a way it’s deceptive – you need to be revisiting all the steps regularly.

 

So, this is the end of our Introduction to Sustainable Funding mini-course. What do you need to do now?

 

Decide what your most urgent action needs to be – perhaps the sun tool or the income spectrum could help you.

 

Check the materials you already have – are you communicating your Outputs, Outcomes and Impact clearly? Are you able to justify your costs if asked?

 

Work out any ‘gaps’ in your knowledge, skills or systems that could hold you back.

 

Make sure you can keep up momentum – it’s very easy to lose sight of your goals when your workload is heavy. Perhaps signing up to our newsletter, booking into a more advanced course or arranging a meeting with relevant people could help.

 

So, in this Introduction to Sustainable Funding course we’ve covered the ‘income spectrum’ – looking beyond raising money from just one source to thinking wider to all potential sources of funding – gifts and donations, grants, contracts, trading and loan finance or social investment. We’ve taken you through some of the features of each of these and the current trends they are experiencing. And then in this section we’ve placed funding in a wider context, showing you a way you can assess how sustainable your organisation is and explaining some key terms you will need to learn.

 

Take a look at the AYMN website for all our sustainable funding tools and resources. Now you’ve completed this introductory course, it might be that you want to take Sustainable Funding further with one of our more advanced. Or, if you think you need more bespoke or in-depth support, then perhaps consultancy would be more suitable. Again, you can find all our resources, including information about AYMN consultancy, on our website. Many of the tools we use in our training courses are free to download too. I hope you’ve found this course helpful. If you take away only two things please remember, 1. Being sustainable is about resource-raising, not fundraising and 2. Sustainable funding can only be successful when integrated and understood by your whole organisation – it is a team activity.

 

Thank you

Hello and welcome to the second of the three instalments of this short course on sustainable funding – or as we sometimes put it – how to keep on keeping on.

As a quick recap of what happened in the first instalment we looked at the main reasons of why sustainable funding seems so distant to many not-for-profits and it is because of the simple fact that we simply don’t set out with it in mind. We don’t plan for it. We’re too busy focusing on helping others to be bothered to help ourselves. We also looked at the ABCs of sustainable funding and the four different income types – Donation, Grants, Contracts and Trading. In this session, we’re setting our sights on the trends of each the income streams and looking at what the trends means for you. And, rather bravely some would say, we’re also go to try and convince you that profit is not a naughty word, even in the not-for-profit sector, rather, it is a word must become part of our lexicon if we are genuinely serious about creating a more equitable and equal world.

So, let’s not waffle any further, let’s get to it.

The first thing to understand in our quest for social equity and equality is that not all income sources are created equal.  Each type of income has characteristics that make them more appropriate to some organisations, and less so to others and it is these distinctions, when clearly understood, that allow programs to fine tune their sustainable funding models. So let’s have look at an example of some of these differences.

Let’s start with contracts - there are many factors which can affect whether an organisation is able to bid for contracts - their size for example. They may not have enough staff with enough time to put a bid together, or their track record may preclude them from bidding altogether because they haven’t been delivering services for long enough. Many contracts also require organisations to have a good chunk of money in the bank as payment won’t be given until the project is complete. These differences can mean that funders often need to lean towards larger organisations or those who can form partnerships.  Equally, many forms of gift fundraising have their own variations and often need organisations to have a strong relationship with their community or a popular ‘brand’ and strong marketing skills.

These different characteristics mean that whilst looking at trends can be useful, you need to be aware of hidden variation.

We’re now going to explore some of the main characteristics and trends of each different type of income.

Donations are great as they normally give you unrestricted income however they can be unpredictable. You can’t always plan on someone making a large donation or leaving you a bequest. There are lots of different types of donor and ways to give but it takes time build up a strong donor base.

Let’s now look at trends in donations, and what you need to think about if you want to increase your income in this area.

Firstly we are a spectacular nation of givers both in time and money. A percentage of 65% per cent of adult Australians donated to charitable causes in 2014. Levels of giving by individuals have remained more or less stable over the past 4 years.

People are most likely to give to causes that support medical research or children & young people. Other popular causes are overseas aid and hospitals. Health and cultural organisations also provide a strong pull. Donors give to causes that are close to their hearts and causes that they believe it.

Buying charity merchandise is the most popular method of giving with 50% saying they give to charities this way but this was closely followed by cash with 49% of all donors who gave gave in cash. Women are most likely to give money.

Legacies and bequests are an important source of income but still only 7 per cent of people in Australia leave a charitable gift in their will. So this is an untapped market as many people are not aware of the option to leave a gift when they write their will. Don’t be afraid to ask, especially from donors that you know well. As a guide the size of the bequest market in the UK is £2 billion a year or $3.5 billion which is greater than the entire fundraising efforts of Australia combined.

If you want to increase gifts you will need to think about donor motivation and why someone would want to give to your cause. This can help you to start thinking about how you could attract that type of donor.

It is advisable to offer your donors as many different methods to give as possible however the trends show us that different donor groups can favour different methods of giving. For example online donations are increasing and are favoured by both those aged 25 to 44 and the over 60’s. New research from shows us that there is a real increase in online giving and more is given online than face to face.

Now let’s look at Grants.

A grant is often restricted income which means that the funder has put conditions on what the money is spent on. There is normally a formal (and competitive) application process and the funder has outcomes of their own that they want to be met. Funders will require you to submit monitoring information, to show how you’ve spent the grant. Unspent funds may have to be returned to funder but this is often negotiable. You will normally have a grant agreement, terms and conditions or even a contract

We think grants are really important for the voluntary sector, and there are still plenty of grant programmes out there. There’s no doubt, though, that there is increased competition for funds. So let’s look at the other trends

Public sector grants still count for a huge proportion of the voluntary sector’s income, though it is likely that government spending cuts will continue into 2016. Many local authorities have scaled back or cut their grant programmes completely.

Trusts and Foundations have also reported an increase in the number of ineligible applications and this says two things 1. many organisations are desperate for resources and 2. the shot gun approach to grant funding doesn’t work as ineligible applications will go straight in the bin.                        

Smaller trusts tend to ‘go with who they know’ – so go back to your funders and make a new proposal to them.

Funders are increasingly looking for grant holders to demonstrate the social impact of their work. When done badly, this can increase the monitoring burden on voluntary organisations; however, being able to show your impact is key to attracting new funders and supporters.

There has also been an increase in more engaged grant making. Where grants are offered along with a package of support, think funders like the Impetus Trust.

Now let’s look at Contracts.

With contracts there is always a restriction on how money is spent. There is usually a formal (and often competitive) application or tender process. Profit can be built in to your bid or tender but you need to consider the legal and financial risks if outcomes or outputs are not delivered. GST applies in many cases, depending on the type of services.

The proportion of voluntary sector income from statutory contracts has more than doubled in last 10 years (but with huge variations across the sector). This is in part due to government channelling more funding through a procurement model than a grant model, but also because the sector is gaining experience in winning and delivering contracts.

The ‘Opening up public services’ and payment by results agendas are likely to affect organisations involved in delivering contracts in the future

Payment by Results is the practice of paying providers for delivering services after agreed results have been achieved.

It intends to reward performance, or outcomes, instead of activity, or outputs. It staggers spending and risk between the funder and the provider. If you are not sure what is meant by the terms outcomes and outputs we explain those terms in more depth in part three.

So there is a positive motive, but the current reality is that there is a lack of efficiency and transparency, and Payment By Results can be very difficult for organisations that don’t have the resources to deliver before payment.

Finally, we need to think about Consortia and sub-contracting.

Bigger contracts and demand for partnership working increase the need to work together. Consortia and sub-contracting can provide great opportunities to pool skills and resources, but can also be complex and costly to set up, and you need to be careful about allocation of risk.

So lastly, Trading.

Trading provides unrestricted income. It involves a customer transaction, and customers may not be the same people as your beneficiaries. Something else to note is that you may need to change your legal structure to allow your organisation to trade. Remember that income above certain amount is taxable.

So what are the trends in trading to watch for?

We’ve seen a recent growth in ethical consumerism, as well as a growth in finance providers specialising in supporting social enterprise.

The term ‘Social enterprise’ is increasingly recognised by Government as an important activity in delivering public services.

There’s also more public awareness of trading for social benefits, with initiatives like Jamie Oliver’s Fifteen restaurant appearing on mainstream television.

In additional to these four types of income, we’re seeing an increased interest in social investment models, where private finance is used to fund a social and financial return.

You may have heard of the ‘Social Impact Bond’, where central government or a social business uses investment from private investors to fund voluntary sector organisations to deliver social outcomes. For example the first UK scheme, launched in 2010 was based on prisoner re-offending rates.

If the outcomes are met, government pays back the investors with interest. It is a way of raising capital when it’s needed, and is a form of payment by results. At the moment there are only a few trials with large organisations. However, there are lots of other forms of social investment, such as small loans to help you bridge a funding gap, or overdrafts to help cash flow when you have a large one-off payment to make.

So, where do you fit?

Look at the income spectrum exercise from the first part of this training. Bearing in mind the general picture across the sector, how do you feel about the long-term stability of your income? Do you think you have a strong enough mix of income? Or are you reliant on one type?

We have an exercise for you to download below, that will help you assess where your organisation’s income sits at the moment, and where your risks lie.

In the final video of this course, we’ll be explaining some key terms and concepts for sustainable funding, exploring how you can assess your organisation’s financial sustainability and providing you with the 7 habits of highly sustainable programs.

Thank you.

I would like to thank Jerry and the award committee for selecting me for this great honor. 

I turned 45 this year and did a fair amount of reflection on my life and I realized that according to actuarial tables I’ve already likely lived more than half of it.  I also reflected on the my professional life path and the decisions I have made over time… it’s just then that I realized I was destined to be a pharmacist.  How you might ask could I determine that?  It’s because all the tough decisions, even early on in my life, have been made using the same principles I use to be the best Pharmacist I could be.  Many of these principles I learned as a MS, PP then Specialty resident here at OSUMC. I would like to share 4 of these with the residents and younger pharmacists this evening. 

The first of these is “take ownership of your decisions”.  We all know them, people who make excuses or refuse to take ownership for their choices in their professional and/or personal lives. I have found that it’s not because they aren’t smart or gifted in life, but it’s because they are unable to make good valued decisions or are afraid or embarrassed of the consequences of making decisions with limited empirical data. 

    Well as I say to my pharmacy students and faculty at St. John Fisher College on a daily basis, we need to prepare ourselves for the “grey zone.”  Think about it, our physician colleagues are not going to ask us questions they can look up in 30 seconds on their iPhone, they ask us questions were there is little to no data and they want us to give them a valued judgment based on the principles of pharmacotherapy, not random facts that we memorized in pharmacy school or in residency.  I believe this is analogous to life decisions, if we are grounded in moral and ethical principles and stick to these principles we can sleep soundly at night.  Even if these decisions turn out to be inaccurate you can have satisfaction in knowing you did the best you could. 

    Now as residents and younger pharmacists many of you are not as grounded in principles of pharmacy practice as others who have more experience.  That is the whole idea of residency, this time right now, this one or two extra years of residency training not only helps you gain confidence in your practice of pharmacy but instills in you principles of practice that will last your entire professional career.  So take advantage of this time then and soak them up! OSUMC is a very special place…You have preceptors here to help you as they did me to find your way.

   Second, we all make mistakes, use them as life lessons and learn from them.  Not just in detail, but look for the larger principle.  One of the most difficult life lessons I learned was as a MS resident at OSUMC.  I spent many a busy weekend in the IV room checking IV’s, preparing and checking chemo and TPN’s as many of us did.  This was my only exposure to being a practicing traditional pharmacy, the rest of the time I was working on projects and in class.  One particular weekend I made a single key stroke error on a neonatal TPN.  That simple key stroke error resulted in me programing the device to deliver 100 x the intended amount of Na.  This error was not picked up for 3 days and the babies serum Na rose to ~180 mEq/L (high normal is 150).   When I was told I was devastated.  I have been through rough times, especially as a young corpseman on the battle field in the 1st Gulf war.  You see right about them my wife Kristen and I were trying desperately to have a child and the fact that I put a baby’s life in jeopardy weighed heavy on my heart. After my devastating experience making a medication error I learned that bench work involving hand eye coordination and maintaining long stretches with meticulous attention to detail within a busy noisy area is not an area in which I could thrive.  I had no problem with the cognitive stuff like answering questions in pressure situations and having a passion for clinical practice, research and most of all finding creative ways to address practical problems.  I also realized that I needed to be a Pharmacist first, not a manager or a student or even a researcher, but a pharmacist.  The truth is I still struggle with this today.  I have over 30 direct reports and always try to be there for them and all my students, but I need to still practice in order for me to be true to who I am.  That is something I will never give up. 

This leads me into my next life lesion: find your way professionally that allows you to put yourself in a position to be your definition of successful.  I want to be clear here…Success is a subjective metric that only you can determine with specific granularity.  This is something I learned from Jerry very early on in residency and never forgot it.  For me …I’m not a guy who is good at checking medication, that’s not my strength.  I found this out using reflection as a means to listen to myself and find out where my strengths and passions align.  But rather my strength turned out to be working with young pharmacists and pharmacy students to help them find their way.

       As an OSUMC MS resident I struggled for many of the reasons I outlined earlier and realized I needed to be actively engaged in practice.  It was not that the program wasn’t challenging or that I didn’t like taking classes and projects, but it wasn’t for me at that point in my life.  So then I changed to the PP residency at OSUMC.  Then it happened!  I found ID again…  You see in pharmacy school I enjoyed ID and did well in it, but I also did well in other areas as well.  But, now it just clicked with me and I had a program director that pushed me to not only challenge myself as a clinician but as a researcher and educator as well.  Dr. Goff had high expectations which was what I liked about her.  She didn’t want excuses, but rather emphasized creativity and gave me the tools to thrive and be successful.  That final year for me at OSUMC was a glimpse into what I wanted to do.  Have a career filled with challenging clinical practice, meaningful research and work with students and post-doc to help shape their careers like Debbie and Jerry did for me.

  The last life lesion I would like to leave you with is to give back.  One of my favorite scriptures from the bible is “for those who much is given, much is expected”.  This means that those of us who are privileged enough to have trained at such a wonderful place, we have to be resolute in  our commitment to providing similar experiences for our young clinicians where we practice.  I’m reminded of this every day, when I look up from my desk at work and see words “message to Garcia on a small green book that was given to me just over 11 years ago by folks that invested everything in helping me find my way.  I’ll close with a simple thank you to of you who helped me along the way.  OH…IO.

In this next series of lessons, we'll be discussing how you can use a/b testing, otherwise known as split testing, to improve your conversion rate. But first, we should answer the question: what exactly is a/b testing?

The best way to describe what a/b testing is is to give you an illustration. Imagine that, one hot summer day, little Sam and Sally are selling lemonade from a little stand on their driveway in their busy neighborhood. There is a sign on the table that says "Lemonade - 25 cents". To the right of the sign is a pitcher of lemonade and a stack of plastic cups. So far, out of 6 people that have walked by, only 1 person stopped and purchased a cup of lemonade. And that was 3 neighbors ago.

Sam says with a defeated frown to Sally, "I wish we could sell more lemonade."  A few seconds goes by... Then she says to Sam, "Hold on." She rushes back inside the home. A couple minutes later, she comes out with a bowl containing a few slices of lemon and a notebook and pen. As she sits down, Sally takes out the notebook and draws a line down the middle of a page, dividing the page into two columns. She writes "A" at the top of the first column and "B" at the top of the other. She then puts an "X" in the  "A" column. 

She then says to Sammy, "I wanna try something." With that, she dumps the lemon slices into the pitcher of lemonade.

"Hey! We don't need more lemons... It's already yummy!" Sam objects.

"Let's just see what happens."

A few minutes later, a lady walks by and sees the lemonade. "My, doesn't that look good! Can I buy a cup please?"

Sam and Sally smile as they sell another cup of lemonade. While the lady drinks the lemonade, Sally puts a check mark in the "B" column. 

As the lady walks away, Sally reaches into the pitcher and pulls out all of the lemon slices with a fork and places them back into the bowl that they were originally brought in. She then puts the bowl away out of sight.

"What are you doing?!!" asked Sam, who was now very confused. "The lemons worked... Why did you take them out?"

"Let's just see what happens."

A few minutes later, a man walked by. "I could use some of that kids. I'd like one lemonade please."

Once the man walked away, Sam gloated, "I guess we didn't need those stupid lemons." Sally ignored him and wrote a check mark in the "A" column. She then dumped the lemon slices back in. "Oh come on!" Exclaimed Sam. "We don't need the stupid lemon slices!"

And this continued for the rest of the morning. Sally would take the lemon slices out after one person and then would remove them for the next. Back and forth. Back and forth. And when a neighbor bought lemonade, she'd put a checkmark in the corresponding column. But when the neighbor walked on by without a lemonade, an x.

At the end of the morning, they brought everything back to the house. Sally counted the x's and checkmarks. Sam looked on as she wrote a 3 under column a and 5 under b and circled it. Sally concluded, "I think having the lemon slices was a good idea." 

The next weekend was even hotter and Sally repeated her experiment. Sam was starting to get curious if this was really going to work. A few hours later, she tallied the results... 2 in column a and 5 in column b. "See?" Sam gloated, " I told you we needed the lemons!"

What Sally did was perform a basic example of split, or a/b testing. Did you notice how she would go back and forth with each new potential customer? And how she kept careful track? And then, she came to a conclusion of which test she thought was the winner.

But there's it didn't stop there, did it? No. She tested it again the following weekend. 

What do you suppose she did the week after that? Well, once both Sam and Sally felt they tested the lemon slices enough and were pretty sure that they sold more with the slices, Sally tried a new variation. Of course, it wouldn't be wise to leave the lemons out. So she left them in. But Sam was really confused when he saw Sally bringing out another pitcher of lemonade. 

"What are you doing? We can't sell that much lemonade! And Mom's gonna kill you... That's her nice pitcher!" said Sam.

"Just chill out." And Sam did. He watched as, with every neighbor that passed by, Sally would now swap between the two pitchers of lemonade and keep track of which pitcher was selling more. The original pitcher with the lemon slices was now the a column. And the new pitcher was now the b column.

You see, Sally wondered if Mom's nicer crystal pitcher would make the lemonade look tastier and help them sell more. And it turned out she was right.

So you see, a/b testing isn't just something you do one time. It's an ongoing process. And the theory is that, with each iteration, you will improve (or learn what hurts) your conversions. And you probably noticed that she only made one change at a time. Why do you think? ** PAUSE ** That's right! If she tried all kinds of ideas at once, she wouldn't necessarily know which ideas worked or didn't. With one change at a time, there's less chance of messing it up. But there is a way to test multiple changes at once in a systematic way. This is called multi-variate testing, and we'll cover that a couple lessons from now.

Now that you know what split testing, otherwise known as a/b testing, is, how would you use this valuable skill in your online marketing? That's the subject of our next lesson.

Hello and welcome to home stretch of this short course on sustainable funding. In this section were going to be discussing some key terminology, talking through the 7 habits of highly sustainable organisations and we’ll also show you a tool that you can use to work out where on the sustainability spectrum you sit.

So we’ll begin with looking at some key terms you may come across when looking at income holistically. It is important to understand these, not just because you might hear others using them – particularly funders – but because they contribute to sustainability.

 

The first is Full Cost Recovery.

 

There are lots of different tools available to help you to work out full cost recovery, but the most important thing is to understand what it means and be aware of how it is reflected in your income generating and planning.

 

Full Cost Recovery is a process by which organisations make sure that they are raising the real amount they need to cover the costs of their activities. All too often costs can be ‘hidden’ and therefore not budgeted for and not included in fundraising. For instance, even volunteers are likely to have costs attached to them – they’ll need some sort of management, they might use your building or your stationary and computers. And what would happen if a key volunteer couldn’t help you anymore? What would it cost to get this help elsewhere?

 

So, when you’re budgeting, you’ll need to work out how to allocate a proportion of the relevant costs to volunteers and find out their real cost. Then you need to work out how to raise this money. Perhaps you have decided to pay for it from surplus from elsewhere. Or perhaps you can fundraise for them.

 

Let’s think about some other hidden costs.

 

A project giving support and advice to young people might have some obvious direct costs – staff time working with the young people, the cost of the venue you’ll be using, maybe paying travel expenses. But there will also be a proportion of lots of other costs – management of the project, of the staff involved and the organisation in general, administrative support, insurance and utility bills. Without deciding how much of these this project is using, you don’t know its full cost. This means that you possibly won’t be raising enough money but also that you might not make the right strategic decisions about which projects are the best use of your organisation’s resources. After all, you want to be achieving the most with the resources that you have.

 

You might want to set up a spreadsheet to work this out – so, for instance, you could enter how much time a project spends in the building, and it could apportion building related costs accordingly. You might want to think about how this varies over time. New projects will always take more management time – and probably more admin too, whereas projects that are coming to the end of a grant will require more fundraising, evaluation and possibly reporting.

 

When you add up all the costs your organisation occurs, you should then be able to see which project is using what.

 

The next key terms, Outputs, Outcomes and Impact, you’ve probably heard of, but it’s amazing how many people don’t really understand what they mean, or don’t remember to make them clear.

 

Outputs are the things you actually do. So you might deliver a training course, or talk to 20 people, or produce an art work. Outputs are usually tangible and can easily be evidenced. These are the easy things to record.

 

Outcomes are trickier. They are the things that happened as a result of your outputs. So, you talked to 20 people and as a result, they understood how they could recycle more. How do you demonstrate that they understood? You produce and art work that communicates to visitors to your local shopping centre some of the emotions felt by teenagers.  How do you measure what was communicated?

 

The next term is impact or sometime colloquially known as so what? That’s your impact – your outputs result in outcomes that lead to a change, an impact – the difference you’ve made to people’s lives or the wider world. Sometimes funding applications only ask for outcomes – they almost always mean impact too. And you should be able to provide some evidence – even if it is ‘soft’ evidence of a case study or a quote. If four of the people on your training course went on to use their new skills to get jobs (the outcome) then so what? Well for one participant, this had the impact that he was able to move to a secure home with his family and his son, has been able to settle in at school and his grades have improved

 

It can help to get someone else to check that you are really demonstrating your impact, not just stating your outputs or outcomes. And you should be able to communicate it to anyone, via any media.  To help you to check whether you’re clear on the differences between Outputs, Outcomes and Impact, I’ve written a mini-quiz you can download below.

 

So now for the seven habits of highly sustainable programs

 

Inspired employees go the extra mile

The biggest differentiator between highly sustainable organisations is the employee’s connection with the organisation’s vision. Living an inspiring vision is habit 1 because it is so foundational to both high performance and the other six habits. A senior leadership team that espouses a vision for their organisation that inspires their employees is far more likely to gain employee buy-in, followed by the extra discretionary effort, energy and focus from employees that are essential to achieve sustainable high performance.

A clear strategy points employees in the right direction

Having developed and articulated an inspiring vision and purpose for their organisation, highly sustainable organisations develop clear strategies and goals to achieve that vision and purpose. The vision, purpose, strategies and goals become the single guiding light that points the way for employees and adds focus and urgency to their individual plans, actions and goals. The highly sustainable organisations in our database make a priority of communicating their strategies clearly.

High performing people drive organisational results

One of the most crucial roles of a board is to select, recruit, develop, coach and support the best CEO they can find to lead their organisation. Great CEOs know that they will be far more able to realise their vision and achieve their objectives and goals if they get the right people on the team. They realise that they don’t only need to select and recruit, but also develop, coach and support the best possible team to take the journey with them.

Creating long term customer loyalty

Almost all organisations show some level of commitment to their customers. If they didn’t, they wouldn’t survive. The commitment of highly sustainable organisations is much greater, more structured and thoughtful than low performance organisations. Highly sustainable organisations take a longer term view to customer loyalty. They are more likely to partner with their clients by really getting to know them and how they can serve them better.

Inadequate systems undermine performance

The highly sustainable organisations make sure that their systems are fit for purpose and well integrated as a key enabler for improving productivity and customer service.

6. A willingness to innovate and be radical

Anita Roddick, founder of The Body Shop, exhorted leaders to “be daring, be first, be different, be just”. Hence, sustainability leaders recognise that difficult problems require creative solutions whilst keep social ideals in mind.

7. A long-term perspective on impacts

Sustainable organisations think much longer term longer term than unsustainable organisations. The point in terms of sustainability is that long term thinking is important for leaders  and it is important to make long term plan and look at ways of making things more efficient. You can make all these plans ahead of time and move in the right direction. And our experience is that the employees will really react very well to those kind of long-term plans. You get more out of the employees than you might expect if you embark on such a journey.

For the next part of the course, you will need our ‘Sustainable Sun Tool’, which you can download below. Pause this if you’d like to print out the download now but don’t worry if you don’t have a printer to hand, I’ll talk you through how to use the tool and you can always print it later.

 

So, looking at the Sun Tool, the first thing to notice is that income is actually only just one aspect. Our argument is that no organisation can be sustainable unless fundraising and income generation is supported by other areas. So, for instance, if you have trouble with financial management, you may not be able to provide the information needed to support a funding application, or you’ll have trouble managing the financial procedures once you’ve been successful.

 

To fill out the Sun tool you choose one option from each of the six areas that sounds most like your organisation. You then plot that on the sun – the closer to the middle, the better you’re doing. Then join the dots to make a probably somewhat wonky circle.

 

Pause this here if you’d like to do this now.

 

So, how does it look? Is there one area that stands out as needing some urgent work?

 

You may next want to ask different people within your organisation to complete this tool on their own. Then compare the results. It will be interesting to see where opinions differ and explore why this is. Why don’t you print out a few copies for your next planning day or trustee meeting?

 

So, this is the end of our Introduction to Sustainable Funding mini-course. What do you need to do now?

 

Decide what your most urgent action needs to be – perhaps the sun tool or the income spectrum could help you.

 

Check the materials you already have – are you communicating your Outputs, Outcomes and Impact clearly? Are you able to justify your costs if asked?

 

Work out any ‘gaps’ in your knowledge, skills or systems that could hold you back.

 

Make sure you can keep up momentum – it’s very easy to lose sight of your goals when your workload is heavy. Perhaps signing up to our newsletter, booking into a more advanced course or arranging a meeting with relevant people could help.

 

So, in this Introduction to Sustainable Funding course we’ve covered the ‘income spectrum’ – looking beyond raising money from just one source to thinking wider to all potential sources of funding – gifts and donations, grants, contracts, trading and loan finance or social investment. We’ve taken you through some of the features of each of these and the current trends they are experiencing. And then in this section we’ve placed funding in a wider context, showing you a way you can assess how sustainable your organisation is and explaining some key terms you will need to learn.

 

Now you’ve completed this introductory course, it might be that you want to take Sustainable Funding further with one of our more advanced. Or, if you think you need more bespoke or in-depth support, then perhaps consultancy would be more suitable. Again, you can find all our resources, including information about AYMN consultancy, on our website. Many of the tools we use in our training courses are free to download too. I hope you’ve found this course helpful. If you take away only one thing please remember sustainable funding can only be successful when integrated and understood by your whole organisation – it is a team activity.

 

Thank you.

Global warming is the continuing increase of the average temperature of Earth's surface. But, why is this happening? First, I would like to explain something called The Greenhouse Effect. It is a natural process that warms the Earth’s surface. There are several gases at the atmosphere that absorb some of the radiation emitted by the sun and keep the Earth warm. Without those gases the Earth would be 59 degrees Fahrenheit colder than the present average. For example, Venus, which is closer than Earth to the Sun, would be only about 45 degrees warmer than the Earth if it had the atmosphere like the Earth. But, because Venus has a thick atmosphere made almost entirely of carbon dioxide, its actual surface is about 880 degrees Fahrenheit. That means that the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is relative to the surface temperature.

The Earth’s surface temperature is increasing because we are changing the natural greenhouse. Human activities over the past century have increased the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere causing global warming and climate change. In its recently released Fourth Assessment Report, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a group of one thousand three hundred (1,300) independent scientific experts from countries all over the world, concluded there is a more than 90% probability that human activities over the past two hundred and fifty (250) years have warmed our planet.

The industrial activities that our modern civilization depends upon have raised 35% of the atmospheric carbon dioxide normal levels in the last one hundred and fifty (150) years.

Researches suggest that seven countries are the top contributors to global warming. The United States, China, Russia, Brazil, India, Germany and the United Kingdom.

So far, around 35% of Earth’s ice-free land has been cleared for food production causing deforestation, biodiversity loss and water pollution. According to a 2006 report by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) found that current production levels of meat contribute between 14 and 22 percent of the 36 billion tons of "CO2-equivalent" greenhouse gases the world produces every year. It turns out that producing half a pound of hamburger for someone's lunch releases as much greenhouse gas into the atmosphere as driving a 3,000-pound car nearly 10 miles.

Global warming is already having significant impacts on the planet. It is accelerating the rate of sea level rise putting at risk of flooding coastal cities, especially the United States East Coast. Wildfires are increasing because of higher spring and summer temperatures. As temperature increase, more rainfalls, increasing the risk of flooding events. More frequent and intense heat waves, creating serious health risks that can cause heat exhaustion, heat stroke, and aggravate existing medical condition. Rising temperatures also lead to increase the spread of insect-borne diseases and also respiratory problems because of the air pollution. Severe droughts can lead to disruption to food supplies. These things are happening now and they will only get worse if we do not act.

Climatologists are studying different ways to limit global warming. Two methods would be limiting carbon dioxide emissions and carbon sequestration, either preventing carbon dioxide from entering the atmosphere or removing carbon dioxide that is already there. In order to do that we must replace energy sources that don’t emit carbon dioxide, like wind, sunlight, nuclear energy and underground stream.

Even when larger companies and factories make the major contribution of carbon dioxide, you still can make a change.

Here are some suggestions that you can start doing now.
Adjust Your Thermostat
Move your heater thermostat down two degrees in winter and up two degrees in the summer.

Install a Low-Flow Showerhead
Using less water in the shower means less energy to heat the water.

Change the AC Filter
Clean or replace dirty air conditioner filters as recommended.

Inflate Your Tires
Keep the tires on your car adequately inflated. Check them monthly.

Put on a Sweater
Instead of turning up the heat in your home, wear more clothes.

If you follow these instructions you will save thousands of dollars per year and also you will help to prevent the rising amounts of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.

Learn more about what you can do at stopglobalwarming.org. We have learned by the scriptures that by small and simple things are great things brought to pass. This is your chance to change the world to a better place.

THE ART OF INFLUENCE: a love story

It was another hot and humid Malaysian afternoon as we stood for a moment in the cool shade looking over the beautiful young palms on the hillside.   Then a young Asian lady slowly approached us with a shy smile and said, "do you remember me".  Now we meet a lot of people around the this big blue planet, but this girl was different.  She spoke with a thick french accent, not Asian.  Our minds flipped through past connections and conventions across Asia and France, but we were drawing a complete blank.  She then saved us from embarrassment as she introduced herself and said "I am from France, we met when I was 13 in Germany".  She said we talked to her about our love for Jesus and about our need to love people around the world.  She said those moments with us changed her life.  She told us her story of becoming a follower of Jesus and later studied to become a medical doctor . . .  so she too could help people.  In the shade that day we discovered that she was heading to Cambodia, the land her father had escaped from as a child, to give needy people medical help.  

Wow, we never knew!  Our influence in her life continued over 15 years.

But how does that kind of influence happen?  We believe it starts with "Love".  We try to communicate to people of all ages and races from the place of "Love".  "Influence" is an Art, an Art that begins by understanding what and who are valuable.  If we believe we are the most value persons on earth then we will influence people to serve us, and when everyone thinks they are most valuable . . . we will have total chaos, manipulation and abuse.  But if one's values lead them to believe that all people are created equally important, then influence becomes something for the good of all, not just a few.  Jesus said, "Love one another. As I have loved you, so love one another."  He also said, "love your neighbor as yourself. 

So we too must love ourself.  This is the balance.  Too much self love and we are "better than you" to little self love and we say you are "better without us".

We believe this balance is best understood as we develop a "Love" also for God, the creator and lover of all mankind.  If we believe He loves us and them as well, then we can live to love everyone in the same way as we have been loved.

Martin Luther King Jr. after much pain put it this way, "I have decided to stick with love.  Hate is too great a burden to bear."  He could say this because he was committed to love God, others and himself.  This was the hallmark of one of the most influential men of the 20th century.  

So let's choose to love ALL before we influence ANY, then we can move forward to influence MANY, towards those things that benefit us ALL.  This is the best Love Story anyone could ever read.
Hhad

results.projectTitle: If It’s Lonely at the Top, You’re Not Doing Something Right
results.script:
If It’s Lonely at the Top, You’re Not Doing Something Right 
 
Loneliness isn’t a requirement of leadership; it’s a consequence of selfishness. If you’re a leader and you 
feel isolated, then you’re doing something wrong. Great leaders should be surrounded by people who are helping them get to the top.

This reminds me of the difference between a travel agent and a tour guide. A travel agent will send you on a journey alone. They will give you directions, but only from a distance. From the safety of their own comfort zones. There is really no risk involved, but neither is there any true reward.

A tour guide on the other hand, will walk with you. Step by step. The goal of the tour guide is to lead you on a successful trip and be there with you all along the way. Their drive is to ensure you enjoy the ride as well as grow from your experiences.

Only self-centered leaders travel alone or work like travel agents. Good leaders, like tour guides, don't want to be alone. They want to take others with them to enjoy the ride.

Good leaders stay close to their people in order to sense their needs and know their dreams. These leaders define success as taking their entire team to the top.
